revision.text:
The XVI edition of the '''[[Caribbean Series]]''' (''Serie del Caribe'') was played in {{baseball year|1973}}. It was held from February 1 through February 6 with the champions teams from [[Dominican Republic]] ([[Tigres del Licey]]), [[Mexico]] ([[Yaquis de Obregón]]), [[Puerto Rico]] ([[Santurce Crabbers (baseball)|Cangrejeros de Santurce]]) and [[Venezuela]] ([[Leones del Caracas]]). The format consisted of 12 games, each team facing the other teams twice, and the games were played at [[Central University of Venezuela|UCV Stadium]] in [[Caracas]], [[Venezuela]]. The Series was played to honor the memory of [[Roberto Clemente]], who died on December 31, 1972, during a humanitarian mission to assist victims of the [[1972 Nicaragua earthquake]]. ==Summary== The powerful Dominican Republic team, managed by [[Tommy Lasorda]], captured the competition with a 5-1 record, with the only defeat coming from Venezuela in Game 4. The Dominicans hit a collective .329 average, committed only three errors, and outscored their rivals 44-19. [[Pedro Borbón]] (2-0) led the pitching staff, while OFs [[Jesús Alou]] and [[Manny Mota]] tied in the race for the batting title, with a .500 average (12-for-24). SS [[Bobby Valentine]], who provided opportune hitting and a sharp defense, was named Series Most Valuable Player. The team also featured Ps [[Bruce Ellingsen]], [[Lerrin LaGrow]], [[Charlie Hough]] and [[Dick Tidrow]]; C [[Steve Yeager]]; IFs [[Jim Spencer]] (1B), [[Ted Martínez]] (2B) and [[Steve Garvey]] (3B), and OFs [[Elvio Jiménez]] and [[Von Joshua]]. The Puerto Rico and Venezuela teams, managed by [[Frank Robinson]] and [[Ozzie Virgil, Sr.|Ozzie Virgil]] respectively, were not rivals for the Dominicans and tied in second place with a 3-3 record. Puerto Rico's victories came behind pitching efforts from [[Doyle Alexander]], (2-0, 1.20 ERA, 13.0 IP) and [[Juan Pizarro (baseball)|Juan Pizarro]] (1-1, 5.25 ERA, 12.0 IP). Other significant players in the roster included Ps [[Lloyd Allen]], [[Roger Moret]], [[Bob Reynolds (baseball)|Bob Reynolds]], [[Ramón Hernández (pitcher)|Ramón Hernández]] and [[Mike Strahler]]; C [[Elrod Hendricks]]; IFs [[Tony Pérez]] (1B), [[Jerry DaVanon]] (2B), [[Ron Cey]] (3B) and [[Juan Beníquez]] (SS); Ofs [[Don Baylor]] (LF), [[José Cruz]] (CF) and [[Willie Crawford]], and utilities [[Julio Gotay]] (IF) and [[Angel Mangual]] (OF). Venezuela divided wins and losses against each team. RF [[César Tovar]] (.385 BA) and 1B [[Gonzalo Márquez]] (.381 BA) paced the offense, while [[Diego Seguí]] pitched a complete game, seven-hit shutout with 15 strikeouts. Other support came from P [[Milt Wilcox]] (1-1, 3.27 ERA), 3B [[Manny Trillo]] (.476 SLG, five RBI) and C [[Joe Ferguson (baseball)|Joe Ferguson]] (.423 SLG, five RBI). The rest of the roster included P [[Ed Acosta]], OF [[Tony Armas]], SS [[Bert Campaneris]], P [[Reggie Cleveland]], CF [[Vic Davalillo|Víctor Davalillo]], OF [[Bobby Darwin]], 2B [[Gus Gil|Gustavo Gil]], C [[Dave Ricketts]] and P [[Ed Sprague (pitcher)|Ed Sprague]], among others. The Mexicans, with [[Dave Garcia]] at the helm, posted a 1-5 record and finished in last place. Their only victory came against Venezuela, 3–1, behind the combined pitching performance of the Romo brothers ([[Vicente Romo|Vicente]] and [[Enrique Romo|Enrique]]) and closer [[Al Hrabosky]]. Also in the roster were 1B [[Jim Campanis]], Ps [[Max León|Maximino León]] and [[Rich Troedson]], 3B [[Dave Hilton (baseball)|Dave Hilton]], and OF [[Matt Alexander]]. {| cellpadding="1" width="350px" style="font-size: 90%; border: 1px solid gray;" |- align="center" style="font-size: larger;" | colspan=6 | '''Final standings''' |- style="background:lightblue;" | ||'''Club''' || '''W''' || '''L''' || '''W/L %''' || '''GB''' ||  '''Managers''' |- align="center" style="vertical-align: middle;" style="background:lightblue;" |- | [[Image:Flag of the Dominican Republic.svg|25px]] || [[Dominican Republic]] || 5 || 1 || .833 || – ||  [[Tommy Lasorda]] |- | [[Image:Flag of Puerto Rico (1952-1995).svg|25px]] || [[Puerto Rico]] || 3 || 3 || .500 || 2.0 ||  [[Frank Robinson]] |- | [[Image:Flag of Venezuela (1954-2006).svg|25px]] || [[Venezuela]] || 3 || 3 || .500 || 2.0 ||  [[Ozzie Virgil, Sr.|Ozzie Virgil]] |- | [[Image:Flag of Mexico.svg|25px]] || [[Mexico]] || 1 || 5 || .167 || 4.0 ||  [[Dave Garcia]] |- |} {| cellpadding="1" width="350px" style="font-size: 90%; border: 1px solid gray;" |- align="center" style="font-size: larger;" | colspan=6 | '''Individual leaders''' |- style="background:lightblue;" |'''Player/Club''' || '''Statistic''' || |- align="center" style="vertical-align: middle;" style="background:lightblue;" |- | [[Jesús Alou]] / [[Dominican Republic|DOM]]

{{Year nav topic5|1990|chess}} Events in [[chess]] in 1990;
==Top players==
[[FIDE]] top 10 by [[Elo rating]] - January 1990
# [[Garry Kasparov]] {{URS}} 2800 # [[Anatoly Karpov]] {{URS}} 2730 # [[Jan Timman]] {{NLD}} 2680 # [[Vassily Ivanchuk]] {{URS}} 2665 # [[Mikhail Gurevich (chess player)|Mikhail Gurevich]] {{URS}} 2645 # [[Valery Salov]] {{URS}} 2645 # [[Alexander Beliavsky]] {{URS}} 2640 # [[Nigel Short]] {{ENG}} 2635 # [[Ulf Andersson]] {{SWE}} 2630 # [[Viktor Korchnoi]] {{SUI}} 2625
==Chess news in brief==
*The [[Candidates Tournament|Candidates']] final is held in [[Kuala Lumpur]]. [[Anatoly Karpov]] defeats [[Jan Timman]] 6½-2½ to become [[Garry Kasparov]]'s challenger once more. In a very close match for the [[World Chess Championship]], held in [[Lyon]], Kasparov has just too much for his long-standing rival and ends up retaining his title by a score of 12½-11½. He wins $1.7million in prize money. *Sixty-four players compete at the [[Manila]] [[Interzonal]]. [[Boris Gelfand]] and [[Vassily Ivanchuk]] are joint winners with 9/13. [[Viswanathan Anand]] and [[Nigel Short]] score 8½/13 to finish with a share of third place. *The Women's (Moscow) Interzonal is closely contested by co-winners [[Ketino Kachiani]] and [[Alisa Galliamova]]. [[Nona Gaprindashvili]] is victorious at the Women's (Malaysia) Interzonal. *[[Gata Kamsky]] and Ivanchuk share success at a double round tournament in [[Tilburg]], each scoring 8½/14. *Kasparov wins the Linares chess tournament with 8/11. Gelfand takes second place with 7½/11. *[[Yasser Seirawan]] triumphs at the [[Haninge]] tournament with 8½/11, ahead of [[Jan Ehlvest]] and Karpov (each with 7½/11). *[[Alexander Beliavsky]] wins the OHRA tournament in [[Amsterdam]]. *Karpov wins at Biel with 9½/14, ahead of [[Ulf Andersson]] (8/14) and [[Tony Miles]] (7½/14) *[[John Nunn]] is the victor at [[Wijk aan Zee]]'s annual Hoogovens tournament. *Anand and Kamsky tie for first in a strong [[New Delhi]] tournament. *Qualifiers from the GMA's Open tournament series come together in Moscow to contest the final. It is won jointly by [[Jon Speelman]], [[Mikhail Gurevich (chess player)|Mikhail Gurevich]], [[Alexander Khalifman]], [[Zurab Azmaiparashvili]] and [[Evgeny Bareev]]. *One hundred and seven teams take part at the [[Chess Olympiad]], held at [[Novi Sad]]. The USSR win by a good margin, with 39/56. The USA and England share second place on 35½/56, with the USA taking silver medals on tie-break. The best individual rating performances come from [[Robert Hübner]] (gold), [[Murray Chandler]] (silver) and Vassily Ivanchuk (bronze). The Women's Olympiad is won by Hungary, on tie-break from the USSR (both 35/42), with China taking bronze on 29/42. The Polgar family are multiple medal winners, each sister taking gold for her respective board, along with a haul of team and performance rating medals. [[Ketevan Arakhamia]] earns a gold medal for her perfect 12/12 score as first reserve for the USSR. *Charismatic Grandmaster [[Guillermo Garcia Gonzales]] of Cuba is killed in a car accident in [[Havana]], while preparing to take part in the Olympiad. *Kasparov wins a training match against [[Lev Psakhis]] +4, -0, =2 in [[Murcia]], Spain. *A 'Chess Summit', held in [[Reykjavík]], comprises four teams of ten players. The USSR wins (31½/60) ahead of England (31/60), USA (30/60) and a combined 'Nordic countries' team (27½/60). England records its first ever match victory over the Soviet team with a 6-4 result. *Beliavsky, [[Leonid Yudasin]], [[Evgeny Bareev]] and [[Alexey Vyzmanavin]] tie for first place in the penultimate [[USSR Chess Championship]], held in Leningrad (soon to be renamed [[Saint Petersburg]]). Beliavsky is awarded the title on tie-break. *[[Lev Alburt]] wins the [[US Chess Championship]] in [[Jacksonville]]. [[Elena Donaldson]] takes the Women's Championship, held in [[Spartanburg]], South Carolina. *[[James Plaskett]] is the winner of the [[British Chess Championship]], held at [[Eastbourne]]. [[Susan Arkell]] is the Women's Champion. *[[Igor Glek]] wins the World Open in [[Philadelphia]]. *Khalifman wins the New York Open and [[Bent Larsen]] takes the ([[Watson, Farley & Williams]]) New York International with 6½/9, ahead of [[Vasilios Kotronias]] (6/9). *The US Masters in [[Chicago]] is won by [[Tony Miles]]. *Karpov wins a game against [[Deep Thought (chess computer)|Deep Thought]] at [[Harvard]]. The program, created by scientists at [[Carnegie-Mellon University]], is remotely attached to an [[IBM]] Mainframe, enabling it to examine 750,000 positions per second. *Seirawan defeats Timman 4-2 in the annual KRO Exhibition Match, held in [[Hilversum]]. This is one in a novel series of matches in which Timman is pitted against his contemporary grandmaster rivals. *The [[World Youth Chess Championship]] for older children is held in [[Singapore]]. [[Sergei Tiviakov]] wins the Boys Under-18, while [[Konstantin Sakaev]] takes the Boys Under-16 trophy. [[Tea Lanchava]] of Georgia wins in the Girls Under-16 category. * The [[World Youth Chess Championship|World Youth Chess Festival for Peace]] caters for the younger children at [[Fond du Lac, Wisconsin|Fond du Lac]], Wisconsin. Although there are categories for girls, Hungarian child prodigy [[Judit Polgár]] enters and wins the Boys Under-14 section. This repeats her (Under-12) achievement at [[Timişoara]] in 1988. [[Boris Avrukh]] of the Soviet Union wins the Boys Under-12 category. *England and the USSR tie for first place in the [[World Chess Solving Championship]]. *[[FIDE]] declares that smoking is prohibited at all of its events. *''[[Shakhmatny Bulletin]]'' ceases publication. *''[[Variant Chess]]'' begins publication.
==Births==
*[[Magnus Carlsen]], Norwegian player, world top five Grandmaster while still a junior - November 30 *[[Sergey Karjakin]], Ukrainian player, youngest Grandmaster ever and a World Youth Champion - January 12 *[[Ian Nepomniachtchi]], Russian Grandmaster, World Youth Champion at U-14 - July 14 *[[Maxime Vachier-Lagrave]], French Grandmaster and national champion - October 21 *[[Dmitry Andreikin]], Russian Grandmaster and former World Junior Champion - February 5 *[[Yuriy Kuzubov]], Ukrainian Grandmaster, one of the world's youngest to gain the title - January 26 *[[Anna Muzychuk]], IM from Ukraine then Slovenia, World Youth Champion for Girls U-16 - February 28 *[[Nguyen Ngoc Truong Son]], Vietnamese player, World Youth Champion at U-10 - February 23 *[[David Howell (chess player)|David Howell]], England's youngest ever Grandmaster - November 14 *[[Puchen Wang]], New Zealand International Master - January 20 *[[Anya Corke]], Hong Kong WGM, winner of three (Open section) British Junior titles - September 12
==Deaths==
*[[Alexander Konstantinopolsky]], Ukrainian honorary Grandmaster, Correspondence player and trainer - September 21 *[[Eero Böök]], Finnish player, honorary Grandmaster and six-time national champion - January 7 *[[Guillermo Garcia Gonzales]], Cuban Grandmaster, three-time national champion - October 26 *[[Ernest Klein (chess player)|Ernest Klein]], former British champion and author - ? *[[Emil Josef Diemer]] - German player and openings theorist - October 10 *[[Geza Fuster]], Hungarian-Canadian International Master - ? *[[Ernest Pogosyants]], Ukrainian chess problemist and endgame study specialist - August 16 *[[Baldur Honlinger]], prominent Austrian player of the 1920s-1950s - March 12 *[[Heinrich Reinhardt]], German-Austrian player - June 14

{{Infobox football club | nickname = '''Al-Shababi'''
(''The Youth''(s)) | ground = [[Al-Seeb Stadium]]
[[Barka, Oman]] | capacity = 14,000 | season = [[2014–15 Oman Professional League|2014–15]] | pattern_la1 = _3_stripes_cut | pattern_la2 = _3_stripes_cut | pattern_b2 = |pattern_ra1=_3_stripes_cut |pattern_ra2=_3_stripes_cut | leftarm1 = 16384D | leftarm2 = FFFFFF | body1 = 16384D | body2 = FFFFFF | rightarm1 = 16384D | rightarm2 = FFFFFF | shorts1 = 16384D | shorts2 = FFFFFF |socks1=FFFFFF |socks2=16384D | clubname = | image = File:Al-ShababClubOmanLogo.jpeg | image_size = 250 | fullname = Al-Shabab Club | founded = {{Start date and age|2003}} | chairman = {{Flag icon|OMA}} '''Sheikh''' [[Hamza Abdulraheem Al-Balushi]] | manager = {{flagicon|Oman}} [[Waleed Zaid Al-Saadi]] | league = [[Oman Professional League]] | position = '''10th''' | website = http://www.shabab-club.com/ | pattern_b1 = }} '''Al-Shabab Club''' ({{lang-ar|نادي الشباب}}) is an [[Football clubs of Oman|Omani sports club]] based in [[Barka, Oman|Barka]], [[Oman]].{{cite web | url = http://www.national-football-teams.com/club/9486/2013_1/Al_Shabab_Seeb.html | title = Al-Shabab Barka | publisher = national-football-teams.com}} The club is currently playing in the [[Oman Professional League]], top division of [[Oman Football Association]]. Their home ground is [[Al-Seeb Stadium]]. The stadium is government owned, but they also own their own personal stadium and sports equipment, as well as their own training facilities. ==Being a multisport club== Although being mainly known for their football, Al-Shabab Club like many other clubs in Oman, have not only football in their list, but also [[field hockey|hockey]], [[volleyball]], [[Team handball|handball]], [[basketball]], [[badminton]] and [[squash (sport)|squash]]. They also have a youth football team competing in the Omani Youth league. ==Colors, kit providers and sponsors== Al-Shabab Club have been known since establishment to wear a full [[blue]] or [[white]] (Away) [[Kit (association football)|kit]] (usually a darker shade of blue). They have also had many different sponsors over the years. As of now [[Kelme (company)|Kelme]] provides them with kits. ==Honours and achievements== Al-Shabab Club – [[2014–15 Oman Professional League]] ===National titles=== *'''[[Oman Professional League]]''' (0): :*Runners-up [[2011–12 Oman Elite League|2011–12]]. *'''[[Sultan Qaboos Cup]]''' (0): *'''[[Oman Professional League Cup]]''' (1): :*Winners [[2017–18 Oman Professional League Cup|2017-18]]. *'''[[Oman Super Cup]]''' (0): ===UAFA competitions=== *'''[[GCC Champions League]]''': 1 appearance :*[[2012–13 GCC Champions League|2012–13]] : Group Stage ==Personnel== ===Technical staff=== {| class="wikitable" |- !Position !Name |- |Head Coach |Salim sultan al nahashi |- |Assistant Coach | |- |Goalkeeping Coach |{{flagicon|Oman}} [[Maqbool Al-Balushi]] |- |Team Manager |{{flagicon|Oman}} [[Abdulkareem Al-Farsi]] |- |Team Manager |{{flagicon|Oman}} [[Juma Bani Abdraboh]] |- |Club Doctor |{{flagicon|Oman}} [[Mashaka Yaqoob]] |- |rowspan=2|Fitness Coach |{{flagicon|Oman}} [[Talib Al-Qasmi]] |- |{{flagicon|Oman}} Ahmed Adil |- |Under-23 Team Head Coach |{{flagicon|Oman}} [[Husain Rustam]] |- |Under-23 Team Assistant Coach |{{flagicon|Oman}} [[Abdulaziz Al-Tarshi]] |- |Under-23 Team Manager |{{flagicon|Oman}} [[Sultan Al-Faidhali]] |- |Under-20 Team Head Coach |{{flagicon|Oman}} [[Basheer Al-Busaidi]] |- |Under-20 Team Assistant Coach |{{flagicon|Oman}} Khalid Al-Hamdani |- |Under-20 Team Manager |{{flagicon|Oman}} [[Abdullah Al-Mushaifari]] |} ===Management=== {| class=wikitable |- !Position !Staff |- | Chairman || '''Sheikh''' [[Hamza Abdulraheem Al-Balushi]] |- | General Secretary || [[Ala'a Al-Riyami]] |- | Vice-President || [[Khalid Al-Yahmadi]] |- | Board Member || [[Khalid Al-Siyabi]] |- | Board Member || [[Idrees Al-Farsi]] |} ==Presidential history== Below is the official presidential history of Al-Shabab Club, from when '''Sheikh''' [[Abdulmoneim Abudllah Al-Farsi]] took over at the club in 2003, until the present day. {| class="wikitable" |- ! To |- |{{Flag icon|OMN}} '''Sheikh''' [[Abdulmoneim Abudllah Al-Farsi]] |2003 |2004 |- |{{Flag icon|OMN}} '''Sheikh''' [[Sulaiman Hamoud Al-Busaidi]] |2005 |2012 |- |{{Flag icon|OMN}} '''Sheikh''' [[Hamza Abdulraheem Al-Balushi]] |2012 |present |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/oman/alshabab/12566/ Al-Shabab Club Profile at Soccerway.com] *[http://www.goalzz.com/main.aspx?team=5838 Al-Shabab Club Profile at Goalzz.com] {{DEFAULTSORT:Al-Shabab Club (Oman)}} [[Category:Football clubs in Oman]] [[Category:Oman Professional League]] [[Category:Seeb]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 2003]] [[Category:2003 establishments in Oman]] [[Category:Omani sport stubs]] [[Category:Asian football club stubs]] {{Oman-footyclub-stub}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Refimprove|date=March 2016}} As in the 1980s, the 1990s in boxing's popularity focused on all divisions. When 1980s legends [[Sugar Ray Leonard]], [[Thomas Hearns]], as well as others retired, newer superstars filled the void: [[Pernell Whitaker]], [[Julio César Chávez]], in the early 1990s, [[Oscar De La Hoya]], [[Félix Trinidad]], [[Roy Jones Jr.]] and [[Floyd Mayweather, Jr.]] in the mid to late 1990s.
As for the heavyweight division, [[Mike Tyson]]'s reign ends prematurely with the upset loss to [[Buster Douglas]]. Former cruiserweight champion, [[Evander Holyfield]] took over as the undisputed champion of the division, and later built a rivalry against former Olympic silver medalist, [[Riddick Bowe]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edmontonjournal.com/sports/riddick-bowe-and-other-monsters-dominated-a-decade|title=Riddick Bowe and other monsters dominated a decade|author=Warren Tasker More Warren Tasker|work=Edmonton Journal|accessdate=March 28, 2016}}</ref> The later 1990s was dominated by [[Lennox Lewis]] who unified the division in 1999.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=vCgM4VYsph8C&pg=PA98&lpg=PA98&dq=Boxing+in+the+1990s&source=bl&ots=bwkw1PbXTF&sig=oxrZyD76hQ7AiwWKVW5Tzh2rP0Y&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjWl7P8lt_LAhUBsxQKHTmNBRI4ChDoAQhJMAk#v=onepage&q=Boxing%20in%20the%201990s&f=false|title=The 1990s|publisher=|accessdate=March 28, 2016}}</ref>
The 1990s also saw the emergence of the battles between the British super middleweight fighters [[Chris Eubank]], [[Michael Watson]] and [[Nigel Benn]], all of whose careers ended in tragedy.
==List of notable fights by year==
===1990=== *February 10 – [[Buster Douglas]] upsets [[Mike Tyson]] by 10th-round KO in Tokyo, to become the undisputed heavyweight champion of the world. Douglas was a 42–1 underdog.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2015/feb/11/mike-tyson-underdog-buster-douglas-boxing-from-the-vault|title=From the Vault: Mike Tyson is knocked out by 42–1 underdog Buster Douglas|author=Paul Campbell|work=the Guardian|accessdate=March 28, 2016}}</ref> *March 31 – ''[[Julio César Chávez vs. Meldrick Taylor|Thunder Meets Lightning]]'': [[Julio César Chávez]] defeats [[Meldrick Taylor]] by 12th-round KO, for the WBC-IBF light welterweight unification. There was controversy as referee [[Richard Steele (referee)|Richard Steele]] stops the contest with 2 seconds left in the bout and Taylor ahead on the scorecards. *August 11 – [[Pernell Whitaker]] defeats [[Juan Nazario]] by first-round knockout to unify the WBA,WBC,IBF belts and becomes the undisputed lightweight champion of the world. *October 25 – Buster Douglas's short reign as heavyweight champion ends as he loses to [[Evander Holyfield]] by third-round KO. Douglas was very noticeably out of shape, despite being in pinnacle shape in the Tyson fight, eight months and two weeks before. *November 11 – [[Julian Jackson (boxer)|Julian Jackson]] wins by stunning knockout over [[Herol Graham]] by a devastating 4th-round KO for the vacated WBC middleweight title. Graham, ahead in the fight, was knocked out by Jackson by a devastating right hand and was out for five minutes. *November 18 – [[Chris Eubank]] wins the WBO middleweight title by beating [[Nigel Benn]] by 9th round TKO.
===1991=== *February 9 – [[Terry Norris]] soundly defeats [[Sugar Ray Leonard]] by 12-round unanimous decision, and successfully defends his WBC super welterweight title. *April 19 – in his first defense as undisputed heavyweight champion, [[Evander Holyfield]] defeats [[George Foreman]] by unanimous decision. Foreman was surprisingly valiant in defeat despite being 42 years of age. *June 1 – in [[Palm Springs, California]] [[Terry Norris]] knocks out [[Donald Curry]] in the 8th round and successfully defends the WBC super welterweight championship.
===1992=== *June 19 – [[Evander Holyfield]] successfully defends his undisputed heavyweight championship by unanimous decision over [[Larry Holmes]]. *November 13 – [[Riddick Bowe]] defeats [[Evander Holyfield]] by 12-round unanimous decision to become the undisputed champion of the world.
===1993=== *March 13 – [[Michael Carbajal]] wins by KO against [[Humberto González]] to unify the IBF and WBC Flyweight belts. Carbajal got knocked down twice during the fight and came back to knock out Gonzalez late in the seventh round. *May 22 – [[Roy Jones Jr.]] defeats [[Bernard Hopkins]] by unanimous decision to win the vacated IBF middleweight title. *September 10 – [[Julio César Chávez]] and [[Pernell Whitaker]]'s fight for the WBC welterweight title ends in a controversial draw, despite Whitaker seemingly dominating the fight. *October 1 – [[Lennox Lewis vs. Frank Bruno|Lennox Lewis beats Frank Bruno]] in the seventh round by a technical knockout. [[Lennox Lewis|Lewis]] was defending his WBC Heavyweight title. It was the first time that two British-born boxers had fought for the world heavyweight title. *November 6 – [[Evander Holyfield]] defeats [[Riddick Bowe]] by majority decision in their rematch for the WBA and IBF heavyweight titles. A man parachutes to the corner of the ring during the fight and starts a mini riot, the fight is later labelled the [[Fan Man|Fan Man Fight]].
===1994=== *January 29 – [[Frankie Randall]] causes [[Julio César Chávez]] his first defeat in 91 professional bouts, winning the [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] world Jr. Welterweight title in the process, by a split decision in 12 rounds. *April 22 – Michael Moorer defeats Evander Holyfield to win the Lineal,WBA,& IBF Heavyweight Championship *September 24 – [[Lennox Lewis]] loses his WBC championship and undefeated record after getting knocked out by [[Oliver McCall]] in front of his home crowd in London *November 5 – [[George Foreman]] at 45 years old becomes the oldest heavyweight champion defeating [[Michael Moorer]] by knockout in round 10, with Foreman behind in all the scorecards. *November 18 – [[Roy Jones Jr.]] defeats [[James Toney]] by a lopsided unanimous decision to win the IBF super middleweight championship
===1995=== *February 15 – [[Nigel Benn]] defeats [[Gerald McClellan]] by a tenth round TKO for the WBC super middleweight title after being knocked through the ropes in the first round, and knocked down again in the eighth round. McClellan is counted on his knees, then loses consciousness in the ring and is transported to hospital, where he falls into a coma and suffers extensive brain damage, losing his eyesight and becoming 80 percent deaf. *May 6 – [[Oscar De La Hoya]] unifies the WBO and IBF Lightweight titles in his victory against [[Rafael Ruelas]]. *August 19 – [[Mike Tyson]] defeats [[Peter McNeeley]] in his first comeback fight. *November 4 – Riddick Bowe knockout Evander Holyfield in the 8th round
===1996=== *March 16 – [[Mike Tyson]] defeats [[Frank Bruno]] by third round KO to win the WBC heavyweight title. *June 7 – [[Oscar De La Hoya]] defeats [[Julio César Chávez]] by fourth round KO to win the WBC light welterweight title. *July 11 – [[Andrew Golota]] gets disqualified during the seventh round of a fight against [[Riddick Bowe]] at [[Madison Square Garden]] for striking low blows against Bowe. A massive riot ensues, in which many civilians are injured. *September 7 – [[Mike Tyson]] defeats [[Bruce Seldon]] in one round for the WBA heavyweight title, unifying it with the WBC heavyweight title he already holds. Tupac Shakur, an American rapper, watched the fight but was fatally shot later on that night. He died 6 days later. *September 24 – [[Mike Tyson]] is stripped of the WBC heavyweight title. *November 9 – [[Evander Holyfield]] wins by technical knockout against [[Mike Tyson]] to win the WBA heavyweight title.<ref name="warrentaskermorewarrentasker">{{cite web|url=http://edmontonjournal.com/sports/a-true-warrior-holyfield-slayed-many-dragons-including-tyson|title=A true warrior, Holyfield slayed many dragons, including Tyson|author=Warren Tasker More Warren Tasker|work=Edmonton Journal|accessdate=March 28, 2016}}</ref> *December 14 – [[Andrew Golota]] gets disqualified again against [[Riddick Bowe]] for low blows in their rematch.
===1997=== *February 7 – [[Lennox Lewis]] regains the now vacant WBC heavyweight title against his only conqueror [[Oliver McCall]], in a bizarre bout, where McCall refuses to fight after the third round and begins to cry in the ring forcing the referee to stop the fight in the fifth round *March 1 – [[Sugar Ray Leonard]] returns to the ring after a six-year layoff at the age of 41, but loses a fifth round TKO against [[Héctor Camacho]] and retires for good after the fight. *March 21 – [[Roy Jones Jr.]] loses his WBC light heavyweight title by disqualification to [[Montell Griffin]] for hitting after the fighter was down, suffering the first loss in his career, Jones Jr. was behind on two score cards. *April 12 Oscar De La Hoya defeats Pernell Whitaker by unanimous decision to win the Lineal &WBC Welterweight Championship *June 28 – [[Evander Holyfield]] wins by disqualification over [[Mike Tyson]], after Tyson tries to bite Holyfield's ear twice, to retaliating to Holyfield's headbutts. *August 7 – [[Roy Jones Jr.]] regains his WBC light heavyweight title by first-round knockout in his rematch against [[Montell Griffin]]. *October 4 Arturo Gatti defeats Gabriel Ruelas by fifth round knockout to retained his IBF Super Featherweight Championship *Lennox Lewis defeats Andrew Golota by first round knockout to retained his WBC Heavyweight Championship *November 8 Evander Holyfield defeats Micheal Moore by 8th RTD unifying the WBA and IBF Heavyweight Championship *December 19 Naseem Hamed defeats Kevin Kelley by fourth round knockout to retained his WBO Featherweight Championship
===1998=== * March 28 Lennox Lewis defeats Shannon Briggs by fifth round knockout to retained his WBC Heavyweight Championship and won the Lineal heavyweight title *July 18 Roy Jones Jr defeats Lou Del Valle by unanimous decision to unify the WBC & WBA Light Heavyweight Championship *August 22 Ivan Robinson defeats Arturo Gatti by split decision the fight was named fight of the year by ring magazine *October 3 [[Floyd Mayweather, Jr.]], aged 21, defeats [[Genaro Hernández]] to win the ''Lineal'' & WBC Super featherweight titles, becoming the first 1996 U.S Olympian to win a world title. *December 12 [[Fernando Vargas]] at 21 years of age, defeats [[Yori Boy Campas]] to win the IBF light middleweight title* * Ivan Robinson defeats Arturo Gattii in the rematch by unanimous decision *December 19 Floyd Mayweather Jr defeats Angel Manfredy by second round knockout to retained his WBC & Lineal Super Featherweight Championship * David Tua defeats Hasim Rahman by tenth round knockout IBF Heavyweight eliminator
===1999=== *March 13 – WBA and IBF champion [[Evander Holyfield]] and WBC champion [[Lennox Lewis]] meet in a unification heavyweight bout at Madison Square Garden, but the fight ends in a controversial draw. *June 5 – [[Roy Jones Jr.]] defeats [[Reggie Johnson (boxer)|Reggie Johnson]] and successfully unifies the light heavyweight division becoming the undisputed champion of the division. *September 18 – in what was billed as the [[Fight of the millennium]], [[Félix Trinidad]] defeats [[Oscar De La Hoya]] by a controversial majority decision. The fight generated 1.4 million pay per view buys generating a record for a non-heavyweight fight. *November 13 – [[Lennox Lewis]] becomes the undisputed heavyweight champion of the world in his rematch against [[Evander Holyfield]] by unanimous decision.<ref name="warrentaskermorewarrentasker"/> *December 4 Fernando Vargas defeats Winky Wright by majority decision to retained his IBF Light Middleweight Championship Diego Corrales defeats John Brown by unanimous decision to retained his IBF Super Featherweight Championship
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Boxing History}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Boxing In The 1990s}} [[Category:History of boxing| 1990s]] [[Category:1990s in sports]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Redirect|Matador}} {{Redirect|Torero}} {{for|the rodeo performer also called a "bullfighter"|Rodeo clown}} {{More footnotes|date=May 2010}} [[File:Eljuli 02.jpg|thumb|''[[El Juli]]'', a famous bullfighter]]
A '''bullfighter''' is a performer in the sport of [[bullfighting]]. "'''''Torero'''''" ({{IPA-es|toˈɾeɾo|lang}}) or "'''''toureiro'''''" ({{IPA-pt|toˈɾɐjɾu|lang}}) (both from Latin ''taurarius'', bullfighter) are the Spanish and Portuguese words for bullfighter and describe all the performers in the sport of [[bullfighting]] as practised in Spain, Portugal, Mexico, Peru, France, and other countries influenced by Portuguese and [[Spanish culture]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.networkeurope.org/feature/bullfighting-in-france-brutal-sport-or-national-culture|title=Network Europe|work=Network Europe|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref> The main performer and leader of the entourage in a bullfight, and who finally kills the bull, is addressed as ''maestro'' (master), or with the formal title '''''matador de toros''''' (killer of bulls). The other bullfighters in the entourage are called ''[[subaltern]]os'' and their suits are embroidered in silver as opposed to the matador's more-theatrical gold. They include the ''[[picador]]es'', ''[[rejoneador]]es'', and ''banderilleros''.
In English, a torero is sometimes referred to by the term '''''toreador''''', which was popularized by [[Georges Bizet]] in his opera ''[[Carmen]]''. In Spanish, the word designates bullfighters on horseback,<ref>{{cite book |date=1901r |title=With the World’s Great Travellers |url=http://www.gutenberg.org/files/35632/35632-h/35632-h.htm |editor1-last=Morris |editor1-first=Charles |editor2-last=Leigh |editor2-first=Oliver H.G. |location=Chicago |publisher=J.B. Lippincott Company |volume=III |page=232 |quote=The actors in the bull-fights are of four classes: ''matadores'', ''banderilleros'', ''picadores'', and ''chulos'', their relative importance being in the order named. The word ''torero'' is a general term for bull-fighters on foot, while ''toreador'' is commonly applied to those on horseback.}}</ref> but is little used today, having been almost entirely displaced by ''rejoneador''.
A very small number of [[List of female bullfighters|women have been bullfighters]] on foot or on horseback; one recent example is [[Cristina Sánchez]]. Female matadors have experienced considerable resistance and public hostility from some aficionados and other matadors.
Usually, toreros start fighting younger bulls (novillos or, more informally in some Latin American countries, vaquillas), and are called ''novilleros''. Fighting of mature bulls commences only after a special match, called "the Alternative". At this same bullfight, the novillero (junior bullfighter) is presented to the crowd as a ''matador de toros''.
The act of bullfighting is not called or considered a stand-alone sport but rather a performance art. There is no contest, simple punctuation, nor any formal classification. Further still, bullfighting, historically, started more with nobles upon horseback, all lancing bulls with accompanying commoners on foot doing helper jobs. As time went by, the work of the commoners on foot gained in importance up to the point whereupon they became the main and only act. Bullfighting on horseback became a separate and distinct act called "[[rejoneo]]" which is still performed today, although less often.
Bullfighting on foot became a means for poor, able-bodied men to achieve fame and fortune, similar to the role of [[boxing]] in many countries. When asked why he risked his life, one famous ''torero'' reportedly answered, ''Más [[cornada]]s da el hambre'' ("[There is] more goring from hunger"). Today, it is common for a bullfighter to be born into a family of bullfighters.
[[File:Matador.JPG|right|250px|thumb|A matador in the Plaza de Toros [[Las Ventas]], [[Madrid]], in the final stage of the bullfight, the ''tercio de muerte'']]
The established term, ''Maletilla'' or ''espontáneo'', is attributed to those who illegally jump into the ring and attempt to bullfight for their sake and glory. While the practice itself is widely despised by many spectators and fans alike, some, such as ''[[El Cordobés]]'', started their very careers this way.
==Types== ===Matador de Toros=== [[Image:MatadorEarly20thCentury.jpg|thumb|Early 20th-century photograph of a matador, showing traditional outfit]] A ''matador de toros'' (lit. "killer of bulls", from [[Latin]] ''mactator'', killer, slayer, from ''mactare'', to slay) is considered to be both an artist and an athlete, possessing great agility, grace, and co-ordination. One of the most famous matadors was [[Juan Belmonte]] (1892–1962), whose technique in the ring revolutionized bullfighting and remains an established standard by which a great deal of bullfighters are judged. The style and bravery of the matador is regarded as being, at least, equally important as to whether or not he actually kills the bull. The most successful ''matadores'' used to be treated like [[pop stars]], with matching financial incomes, cult followings and accompanied by lurid [[Tabloid journalism|tabloid]] stories about their romantic conquests with women.
Currently, however, even today's top matadors earn less, in real terms, than their peers did in the 1960s—and much of mass media coverage is only limited to a handful of matadors known as the "mediáticos", the sum of which do not necessarily include any of the nation's prized bullfighters in [[Spain]].
The great personal danger of bullfighting adds to the performing matador's mystique; matadores are regularly injured by bulls and, concurrently, 533 professional bullfighters have been killed in the arena since 1700.<ref>[[Alexander Fiske-Harrison|Fiske-Harrison, Alexander]]. [https://thelastarena.wordpress.com/2015/02/25/533-professional-bullfighters-killed-in-the-ring-since-1700/ '533 professional bullfighters killed in the ring since 1700'], The Last Arena: In Search Of The Spanish Bullfight blog</ref> One of the most famous bullfighters in history, [[Manolete]], died this way in 1947. The most recent bullfighter to die this way was the matador Iván Fandiño on 17 June 2017 in [[Aire-sur-l'Adour]], France.<ref>[[Alexander Fiske-Harrison|Fiske-Harrison, Alexander]], [https://thelastarena.wordpress.com/2017/06/18/ivan-fandino-we-who-are-about-to-die-salute-you/ 'Iván Fandiño: We Who Are About To Die Salute You…'], The Last Arena: In Search Of The Spanish Bullfight blog</ref> This hazard is said to be central to the nature and appeal of bullfighting.
The American writer [[Ernest Hemingway]] was a bullfighting aficionado. Within his fictional works, ''[[The Sun Also Rises]]'' features a matador and scenes of bullfighting, as do his short stories ''The Capital of the World'' and ''The Undefeated.'' Outside of fiction, he also wrote at length on the subject in ''[[Death in the Afternoon]]'' (1932) and ''[[The Dangerous Summer]]'' (1959).
In 1962, Hollywood producer [[David Wolper]] produced "[[The Story Of A Matador]]", documenting what it's like to be a matador.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.matadorjaimebravo.com/StoryMatador_IntroPage.html|title=Matador Jaime Bravo Official Website -- "The Story Of A Matador"|publisher=|accessdate=15 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150215024905/http://matadorjaimebravo.com/StoryMatador_IntroPage.html|archive-date=15 February 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In this case, it was the late Matador [[Jaime Bravo]].
===Picador=== {{Main|Picador}}
[[File:San marcos bullfight 13.jpg|thumb|A "[[picador]]"]]
A picador is a bullfighter who uses a special [[lance]] called ''pica'' while on horseback to test the bull's strength and to provide clues to the matador on which side the bull is favoring. They perform in the tercio de varas which is the first of the three stages in a [[Spanish-style bullfighting|Spanish bullfight]]. The shape of the lance or pica is regulated by Spanish law to prevent serious injury to the bull which was viewed as unfair cheating in the past. The bull will charge the horses in the ring and, at the moments prior to contact, the picador lances the bull in a large muscle at the back of the neck; thus begins the work of lowering his head. The picador continues to stab at the bull's neck leading to the animal's first major loss of blood. During this time, the bull's injured nape will fatigue—however, as a result of the enraged bull charging, the picador's horse will tussle with avoiding the bull throes at trying to lift the horse with its horns.{{clarification needed|date=April 2017}} The enduring loss of blood and exertion gradually weakens the bull further and makes it ready for the next stage.
In order to protect the horse from the bull's horns, the horse is surrounded by a 'peto' – a mattress-like protection. Prior to 1928, horses did not wear any protection and a bull would frequently disembowel the opposing horse during this vulnerable stage.
===Banderillero===
[[File:Padilla-band.jpg|thumb|A "banderillero"]]
The banderillero is a torero who plants the banderillas (lit. ''little flags''). These are colorful sticks, usually colored with the flag of the banderillero's birthplace, with a barbed point which are increasingly placed in the top of the bull's shoulder. Banderilleros attempt to place the sticks while running as close to the bull as possible. They are judged by the crowd on their form and bravery. Sometimes a matador, who was a particularly skillful banderillero before becoming a matador, will place some of the banderillas himself. Skilled banderilleros can actually correct faults in the manner in which the bull charges by lancing the bull in such a way that the bull ceases hooking to one side, and thereby removing a potential source of danger to the matador by limiting the bull's offensive movements.
==Costume== Because of the decorations and elaborateness of the costume, the Spanish call the torero's outfit as ''[[traje de luces]]'', meaning the "suit of lights". Though undoubtedly flamboyant, matador costume structure provides great ease of movement.
==See also== {{portal|Spain}} *[[Spanish-style bullfighting]] *"[[Operation Matador (disambiguation)|Operation Matador]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fepow-community.org.uk/arthur_lane/Percivals_Report/html/opening_of_hostilities.htm|title=OPENING OF HOSTILITIES|publisher=|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref><ref>[http://www.history.navy.mil/danfs/b1/baffins.htm]</ref><ref name="StudiesIntell85">{{cite web|url=http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/nukevault/ebb305/doc01.pdf|title=Project Azorian: The Story of the Hughes Glomar Explorer|date=Fall 1985|publisher=Studies in Intelligence, [[CIA]]|accessdate=2010-02-13}}</ref> *[[Bullfighting]] *[[List of bullfighters]] *[[Cal State Northridge Matadors]], only intercollegiate sports team with the Matador mascot. *[[San Diego Toreros]], the intercollegiate sports teams of the [[University of San Diego]]. *[[Texas Tech Red Raiders]], formerly the Texas Tech Matadors, are the intercollegiate sports teams of [[Texas Tech University]]. *[[Valencia Community College]] The Matador is the college's mascot.
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Further reading== Poon, Wena. ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20120328051134/http://www.saltpublishing.com/books/smf/9781844717699.htm Alex y Robert]'', Salt Publishing, London, 2010. Novel about an American teenage girl training as a matador in contemporary Spain.
==External links== {{Commons category|Toreros}} *[http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/eticket/story?page=matador "Haunted By The Horns"], (2006) An ESPN online article about Matador Alejandro Amaya and Matador [[Eloy Cavazos]]. The article investigates why a matador chooses their profession. *[http://www.life.com/gallery/59841/female-matadors-a-fierce-beauty#index/0 Female Matadors: A Fierce Beauty] – slideshow by ''[[Life magazine]]'' *[https://statenisland.pastperfectonline.com/webobject/66929D64-0C19-40D9-AD8D-190746320423 Spanish fan with matador illustration, 1887, in the Staten Island Historical Society Online Collections Database]

{{about|the arena in Omaha formerly known as CenturyLink Center|the arena in Bossier City, Louisiana that retains the CenturyLink name|CenturyLink Center (Bossier City)}} {{Infobox building | name = CHI Health Center Omahahttps://www.omaha.com/news/chi-health-center-might-make-it-sound-like-a-hospital/article_b8e1a848-7d58-5603-b393-4942168b72f7.html | logo = | logo_size = 200px | image = http://chihealthcenteromaha.com/App_Themes/QwestCenterTheme/Images/logo-trans.png | image_size = 250px | image_caption = West façade c. 2012 | former_names = Omaha Arena and Convention Center {{small|(planning/construction)}}
Qwest Center Omaha {{small|(2003–11)}}
CenturyLink Center Omaha {{small|(2011–18)}} | alternate_names = CHI Health Center
Omaha Convention Center and Arena | location = [[Downtown Omaha]] | coordinates = {{Coord|41.263|-95.928|display=it}} | address = 455 North 10th Street
[[Omaha, Nebraska]], U.S. | namesake = [[CHI Health]] | groundbreaking_date = {{Start date|2001|03|01}} | opened_date = {{Start date|2003|09|20}} | inauguration_date = {{Start date|2003|09|12}} | relocated_date = | renovation_date = | closing_date = | demolition_date = | cost = [[United States dollar|$]]291 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|291000000|2003}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | owner = City of Omaha | landlord = Metropolitan Entertainment
& Convention Authority | size = {{convert|1118300|sqft|m2}} | architecture_firm = [[DLR Group]] | structural_engineer = [[Thornton Tomasetti|Thornton-Tomasetti Group]] | services_engineer = M–E Engineers, Inc. | main_contractor = Kiewit Construction Co. | seating_capacity = 18,320 {{small|(basketball)}}
17,100 {{small|(hockey)}}
18,975 {{small|(concert center-stage)}}
2,693 {{small|(Peter Kiewit Grand Ballroom)}} | parking = 4,500 spaces | website = }} '''CHI Health Center Omaha''' is an [[arena]] and [[convention center]] in the central [[United States]], located in the North Downtown neighborhood of [[Omaha, Nebraska]]. Operated by the Metropolitan Entertainment & Convention Authority (MECA), the {{convert|1,100,000|sqft|-3|adj=on}} facility has an 18,975-seat arena, a {{convert|194,000|sqft|abbr=on}} exhibition hall, and {{convert|62,000|sqft|abbr=on}} of meeting space. The complex opened {{Time ago|2003|spellout=yes}} in 2003 as '''Qwest Center Omaha''', and adopted the name of '''CenturyLink Center Omaha''' on July 15, 2011, as part of a {{nowrap|$22 billion}} buyout of [[Qwest]] by [[List of CenturyLink operating companies|CenturyLink]] (formerly CenturyTel).{{cite news| title=Name Change Coming For Qwest Center Omaha| last=Sabin| first=Jeff| url=http://www.wowt.com/home/headlines/Name_Change_Coming_For_Qwest_Center_Omaha_118617114.html| work=[[WOWT]] News| date=March 24, 2011|accessdate=March 13, 2017}}{{cite news| title=MECA prepares for new CenturyLink Center naming rights contract| first=Roseann| last=Moring| newspaper=[[Omaha World-Herald]]| date=July 29, 2015}} In July 2018, [[CHI Health]] bought the naming rights to the arena under a 20-year agreement worth $23.6 million,{{Cite news|url=https://www.omaha.com/livewellnebraska/health/so-long-centurylink-center-chi-health-buys-omaha-arena-naming/article_6dd7ef51-d7c1-5e39-a284-cf3ca50f7deb.html|title=So long, CenturyLink Center. CHI Health buys Omaha arena naming rights in $23.6 million deal |first=Emily |last=Nohr |newspaper=Omaha World-Herald |accessdate=August 1, 2018 |language=en}} and the arena was renamed '''CHI Health Center Omaha''' effective September 1, 2018.{{Cite press release|url=https://gocreighton.com/news/2018/6/21/mens-basketball-to-play-at-chi-health-center-omaha.aspx|title=Men's Basketball To Play at CHI Health Center Omaha|website=Creighton Bluejays|language=en|date=June 21, 2018 |accessdate=August 1, 2018}} Just west of the [[Missouri River]], the [[elevation]] at street level is approximately {{convert|1000|ft|-1|spell=in}} above [[sea level]]. The arena hosts [[basketball]] and [[Ice hockey|hockey]] games, [[professional wrestling]] events, [[concert]]s, and the annual shareholders' meeting of Omaha-based conglomerate [[Berkshire Hathaway]], usually held on the first Saturday of May. The arena's primary tenant is the [[Creighton University]] [[Creighton Bluejays men's basketball|men's basketball team]]. Through the 2014–15 NCAA ice hockey season, the [[Omaha Mavericks men's ice hockey|Omaha Mavericks men's ice hockey team]], representing the [[University of Nebraska Omaha]], was also a primary tenant, but the Mavericks moved to the new [[Baxter Arena]] effective with the 2015–16 season.{{cite web |title=UNO Community Arena |url=http://www.unomaha.edu/athletics/arena.php |publisher=[[University of Nebraska Omaha]] |accessdate=February 17, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219160901/http://www.unomaha.edu/athletics/arena.php |archivedate=February 19, 2015 |df= }}{{cite press release|url=http://www.omavs.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=31400&ATCLID=210447114 |title=Mavericks, Baxter Share Spotlight in 4-2 Win |publisher=[[Omaha Mavericks|Omaha Athletics]] |date=October 23, 2015 |accessdate=October 29, 2015}} ==History== In 2000, Omaha voters approved a $216 million bond issue to build a new convention center and arena; the remainder of the $291 million project was provided by private organizations and individuals. The facility design was led by architectural firm [[DLR Group]]. Naming rights to the arena were purchased by Qwest. Qwest Center Omaha opened in September 2003 with an initial [[seating capacity]] of 17,000 for concerts, 15,500 for [[basketball]], and 14,700 for [[ice hockey|hockey]]. In 2006, a $5.7-million expansion of the arena increased capacity by approximately 1,500 seats. The Qwest Center displaced the 1954 [[Omaha Civic Auditorium]] as the city's premier indoor arena. The venerable [[Ak-Sar-Ben (arena)|Ak-Sar-Ben Coliseum]] closed in 2002 and was demolished in 2005. ==Notable events== The arena has hosted games in the [[NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament]] four times: first- and second-round games in [[2008 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|2008]], [[2012 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament|2012]], and [[2015 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament|2015]]; and Midwest Regional games (Sweet Sixteen and Elite Eight) in [[2018 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament|2018]]. The arena also hosted the 2010 NCAA Division I Wrestling Championships, and was home to the [[WWE]] [[Judgment Day (2008)|Judgment Day 2008]] pay-per-view, as well as other events from WWE. ===Summer Olympics Swimming Trials=== The center hosted the nationally televised [[USA Swimming]] Summer Olympics trials in [[Swimming at the 2008 Summer Olympics|2008]], [[Swimming at the 2012 Summer Olympics|2012]] and [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics|2016]]. The center does not have permanent swimming facilities and a team of 200 workers with oversight by Myrtha Pools constructed them in two weeks.{{cite web| url=http://www.nbcolympics.com/news/construction-begins-us-olympic-swimming-trials-pool-venue| title=Construction begins on U.S. Olympic Swimming Trials pool venue| publisher=[[NBC Sports]]| first=Rachel| last=Lutz| date=May 26, 2016}} (which specializes in the construction and dismantling of large scale temporary pools).{{cite web| url=http://www.myrthapools.com/en/types/temporary-pools/| title=Temporary swimming pools construction| publisher=Myrtha Pools}} The Omaha Fire Department pumped in two million gallons of water from hydrants around the center.{{cite news| title=Fire truck begins filling U.S. Olympic Trials pool| url=http://olympics.nbcsports.com/2016/06/07/olympic-trials-pool-video-fire-truck-swimming-omaha/| first=Nick| last=Zaccardi| date=June 7, 2016| work=NBC Sports| accessdate=March 14, 2017}}{{cite journal| title=U.S. Olympic Trials Pool in Omaha Begins Construction 3 Weeks Out| url=https://swimswam.com/u-s-olympic-trials-pool-in-omaha-begins-construction-3-weeks-out/| first=Karl| last=Ortegon| date=June 1, 2016| work=Swim Swam}} The 2008 event averaged more than 12,000 spectators each night.{{cite web| title=U.S. Olympic Trials Will Return to Omaha in 2012| url=http://usaswimming.org/ViewNewsArticle.aspx?TabId=865&itemid=2683&mid=2430| publisher=USA Swimming| date=June 25, 2009| accessdate=March 20, 2015| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402222645/http://usaswimming.org/ViewNewsArticle.aspx?TabId=865&itemid=2683&mid=2430| archive-date=2015-04-02| dead-url=yes| df=}} A storm damaged a portion of the roof known as ''The Hat'' on June 27, 2008. There was no structural damage, but the damage caused water to pour into parts of the Qwest Center, flowed down two sets of arena steps and onto the deck of the competition pool for the [[USA Swimming]] [[Swimming at the 2008 Summer Olympics|Summer Olympic]] Trials. The schedule for the trials went on as planned.{{cite news| title=Severe Storm in Omaha Damages Swimming Arena| first=Beth| last=Harris| url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/olympics/2008-06-27-162924615_x.htm| newspaper=[[USA Today]]| date=June 27, 2008| accessdate=January 6, 2014}} The pools were dismantled after the event and moved to other cities for permanent installation with the 2008 pool going to the Poseidon Swimming facility in [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]], [[Virginia]],{{cite news| title=Pool naming rights given to longtime swim family| first=Wendy| last=Reuer| date=December 15, 2015| url=http://www.westfargopioneer.com/news/3904233-pool-naming-rights-given-longtime-swim-family| work=West Fargo Pioneer}} the 2012 pool going to Charles River Aquatics in [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]]{{cite press release| title=2012 Trials Pool Finds Permanent Home at USA Swimming Club| url=http://www.usaswimming.org/viewnewsarticle.aspx?tabid=0&itemid=3746&mid=8712| date=September 15, 2011| publisher=USA Swimming| access-date=2016-07-24| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160814155141/http://www.usaswimming.org/viewnewsarticle.aspx?tabid=0&itemid=3746&mid=8712| archive-date=2016-08-14| dead-url=yes| df=}} and the 2016 pool going to the Hulbert Aquatic Facility in [[West Fargo, North Dakota]] (West Fargo bought the pool via a local group of swim enthusiasts called UP Aquatics for $900,000).{{cite news| url=http://www.inforum.com/news/3917371-local-swim-group-purchases-olympic-trials-competition-pool-west-fargo| title=Local swim group purchases Olympic Trials competition pool for West Fargo| first=Wendy| last=Reuer| date=January 6, 2016| work=[[The Forum of Fargo-Moorhead]]}} ==Construction== In 2001, construction began on the new convention center and arena, known as the "Omaha Arena and Convention Center". Architectural firm [[DLR Group]] spearheaded the design, while [[Thornton Tomasetti|The Thornton-Tomasetti Group]] served as structural engineer. M–E Engineers, Inc. was the services engineer and a local company, [[Kiewit Corporation]], led general construction. A groundbreaking ceremony was held on March 1, 2001.{{cite news |url=http://theomahachannel.com/oma/news/stories/news-51760720010301-130347.html |title=Arena Plans Take Next Step |date=March 1, 2001 |website=[[KETV]] News |access-date=January 1, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20010303144248/http://theomahachannel.com/oma/news/stories/news-51760720010301-130347.html |archive-date=March 3, 2001}} The venue was completed in August 2003, with an official opening on September 24, 2003. In 2006, the MCEA funded a project to expanded the arena and add an additional 1,472 seats to the upper bowl.{{cite news |url=http://www.wowt.com/home/headlines/1617996.html |title=Qwest Center To Expand |date=June 9, 2005 |work=WOWT News |access-date=January 1, 2016}} The project also included adding restroom facilities and concession stands, as well as updating aesthetics, mechanical systems, and emergency exits. The cost of the project was $6 million. Construction began in May and was completed September 8, 2006. In 2009, the center saw another renovation with work enveloping the entire building. The $6 million project included new carpet, wallpaper, reupholstered arena seating, and a new scoreboard.{{cite web |url=http://omaha.com/article/20091109/NEWS01/711099973 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091111161743/http://omaha.com/article/20091109/NEWS01/711099973 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=November 11, 2009 |title=Qwest ready for face-lift |last1=Tysver |first1=Robynn |date=November 9, 2009 |work=Omaha World-Herald |access-date=January 1, 2016}} ==Facilities== {|class="wikitable" align="right" width=350px style="margin: 25px 0px 50px 25px;" ! colspan="3" style="background: #7ffc03;"|Tenants |- |align="left"|[[Creighton Bluejays men's basketball|Creighton Bluejays]] |align="center"|[[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] |align="right"|2003–present |- |align="left"|River City Rodeo and Stock Show |align="center"|[[Knights of Ak-Sar-Ben|KASB]] |align="right"|2003–present |- |align="left"|[[Omaha Mavericks men's ice hockey|UNO Mavericks]] |align="center"|[[National Collegiate Hockey Conference|NCHC]] |align="right"|2003–2015 |- |align="left"|Nebraska State Wrestling Tournament |align="center"|[[Nebraska School Activities Association|NSAA]] |align="right"|2007–present |- |align="left"|[[United States Olympic Trials (swimming)|United States Olympic Trials]] |align="center"|[[USA Swimming|USA-S]] |align="right"|2008–present |- |align="left"|NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament |align="center" rowspan="3"|NCAA |align="right"|2008, 2012, 2016, 2018 |- |align="left"|NCAA Division I Women’s Volleyball Championship |align="right"|2008 |- |align="left"|NCAA Division I Wrestling Championships |align="right"|2010 |- |} ;CHI Health Omaha Convention Center The convention center has placed Omaha on the convention map since opening in 2003. The center features three exhibit halls, four ballrooms and over 15 meeting rooms. *'''Exhibit Hall''': The main exhibition room which can be divided into three separate rooms (Halls A-C) depending on configuration. The combined rooms can house over 1,000 or a conference seating more than 16,000 guests. *'''Peter Kiewit Grand Ballroom''': Named after the founder of the [[Kiewit Corporation]], is the biggest ballroom in the facility. Based on configuration, it can be divided into 3 small ballrooms (Ballroom A-C) or 2 large rooms (North and South). The room is primarily used for graduation ceremonies, charity galas and business conferences. *'''Junior Ballroom''': This intimate space was designed for private events such as weddings, receptions, banquets and cocktail parties up to 1,000 guests. ;CHI Health Center Arena The arena is the busiest venue of the complex. Built in 2001, the arena was meant to replace the aging [[Omaha Civic Auditorium]] and demolished [[Ak-Sar-Ben (arena)|Ak-Sar-Ben Coliseum]]. It is the largest arena in the state, seating over 18,000. It contains 32 luxury suites and over a thousand club seats. The arena hosts shows of all genres, including: concerts, family shows, sports, rodeos and circuses. The arena opened September 12, 2003, with a private concert by [[Grand Funk Railroad]]. The first official event was the "River City Roundup Fair and Festival", held at both facilities.{{cite web |url=http://www.hpj.com/archives/douglas-county-fair-river-city-roundup-merge/article_c70747c5-75fd-5c91-84e4-4ca94f318017.html |title=Douglas County Fair,River City Roundup merge |author= |date=January 1, 2002 |work=[[High Plains Journal]] |location=Dodge City |access-date=January 1, 2016}} ;Hilton Omaha This hotel features 600 guest rooms, 15 meeting rooms, and two ballrooms, an on-site restaurant, and skywalk connection to the convention center. The $71 million property opened April 2004 and has achieved the [[American Automobile Association|AAA]] four-diamond rating for ten years.{{cite news| title=For 10th straight year, Hilton Omaha gets AAA's four-diamond rating| url=http://www.omaha.com/money/for-th-straight-year-hilton-omaha-gets-aaa-s-four/article_c05f60da-55b7-571a-99a5-8eaa73c75f1c.html| first=Cindy| last=Gonzalez| date=August 3, 2013| work=Omaha World=Herald| accessdate=March 14, 2017}} ==Naming== *Qwest Center Omaha {{small|(September 20, 2003–July 14, 2011)}}{{cite web |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/denver/stories/2003/08/11/daily29.html |title=Qwest buys naming rights for Omaha center |author= |date=August 13, 2003 |work=Denver Business Journal |access-date=January 1, 2016}} *CenturyLink Center Omaha {{small|(July 15, 2011–August 31, 2018)}}{{cite web |url=http://www.omaha.com/article/20110715/NEWS01/110719678 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130130221730/http://www.omaha.com/article/20110715/NEWS01/110719678 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 30, 2013 |title=Qwest Center gets new name |last1=Robb |first1=Jeffery |last2= |first2= |date=July 15, 2011 |work=Omaha World-Herald |access-date=January 1, 2016}} *CHI Health Center Omaha {{small|(September 1, 2018–present)}} ==Records and milestones== 85–77 || align=right|January 27, 2018 |- |} On the evening of March 8, 2014, the largest crowd to attend a Creighton University basketball game occurred when 18,868 fans witnessed the Creighton men's team defeat Providence on [[Doug McDermott]]'s career-high senior night performance of 45 points. On January 13, 2012, the largest crowd to ever watch a hockey game in Nebraska occurred when 16,138 fans attended the game between the University of Nebraska at Omaha and Minnesota-Duluth.{{cite web| title=Brown’s Hat Trick Propels Minnesota-Duluth Over Nebraska-Omaha| first=Matthew| last=Semisch| url=http://www.uscho.com/recaps/2012/01/13/browns-hat-trick-propels-minnesota-duluth-over-nebraska-omaha/| work=U.S. College Hockey Online| date=January 13, 2012| accessdate=March 20, 2015}} The CHI Health Center holds several NCAA attendance records, particularly in women's college volleyball. The three largest crowds to attend NCAA tournament matches were for [[Nebraska Cornhuskers women's volleyball|Nebraska Cornhuskers]] games at the venue. The highest attendance for any volleyball match in the United States, whether for men or women, occurred on December 19, 2015 when 17,561 fans watched the 2015 NCAA Division I Women's Volleyball Championship game between Nebraska and [[2010–14 Big Ten Conference realignment#Nebraska|former conference rival]] [[Texas Longhorns women's volleyball|Texas]]. This broke a record set two days earlier, when Nebraska defeated another former conference rival, [[Kansas Jayhawks|Kansas]], in the national semifinals in front of a crowd of 17,551. In turn, this match broke an attendance record set in 2008, when 17,340 fans watched the [[2008 NCAA Division I Women's Volleyball Tournament#Final Four – Qwest Center, Omaha, Nebraska|NCAA semifinal]] match between [[Penn State Nittany Lions women's volleyball|Penn State]] and Nebraska.{{cite web| title=2008 NCAA Women's Volleyball Championship Match Notes| url=http://www.gopsusports.com/sports/w-volley/recaps/122108aac.html| publisher=Pennsylvania State University Department of Athletics| date=December 20, 2008| accessdate=January 6, 2014}} ==Gallery== {| | [[Image:Creighton Bluejays men's basketball playing (Qwest Center, Omaha, 2007).jpg|thumb|200px|White Out vs Wichita State]] | [[Image:P1270977.JPG|thumb|200px|White Out]] | [[File:Whiteout at Qwest Center.jpg|thumb|200px|White Out vs Southern Illinois]] | [[File:P7050503.JPG|thumb|200px|US Olympic Swimming Trials in June 2008]] |} {| | [[File:First Big East Game.JPG|thumb|200px|2013 Scoreboard & Logo]] | [[Image:Wiki photos 068d.jpg|thumb|200px|View looking southeast]] | [[Image:Wiki photos 059d.jpg|thumb|200px|West façade and main entrance]] | [[Image:QwestCenterOmahaArenaView 2010.jpg|thumb|200px|South façade prior to 2011]] |} ==See also== * [[Omaha Civic Auditorium]] – (defunct) * [[Baxter Arena]] * [[Mid-America Center]] * [[Rosenblatt Stadium]] – (defunct) * [[Ak-Sar-Ben (arena)|Ak-Sar-Ben]] – (defunct) * [[TD Ameritrade Park]] * [[Morrison Stadium]] * [[Ralston Arena]] * [[Werner Park]] * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.chiealthcenteromaha.com/ CHI Health Center Omaha Official Website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120126204237/http://www.gocreighton.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=1000&ATCLID=1147632 CenturyLink Center Omaha – GoCreighton.com] {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = Home of
