{{Infobox rugby team | teamname = Charrua | image = | imagesize = | union = [[Brazilian Rugby Confederation]]
[http://www.fgrugby.com.br/ Gaúcho Rugby Federation] | fullname = Charrua Rugby Clube | nickname = | countryflag= Brazil | founded = June 2, 2001 | region = [[Porto Alegre]], [[Rio Grande do Sul|RS]], [[Brazil]] | ground = ESEF/UFRGS | capacity = | ceo = | president = {{flagicon|BRA}} Uary Gondim | coach = {{flagicon|ARG}} Diego Martin | captain = {{flagicon|BRA}} Diego Pietrobon | top scorer = | caps = | url = charruarugby.com | league = | season = 2011 | position = [[File:Mapa Regiao Sul do Brasil (somente).PNG|22px]] 4th place of Liga Sul
{{flagicon|Rio Grande do Sul}} 3rd of Gaúcho | pattern_la1= | pattern_b1 = Charrua_body_uniforme | pattern_ra1= | pattern_so1= | pattern_sh1= | leftarm1 = CD0000 | body1 = 191970 | rightarm1 = CD0000 | shorts1 = FFFFFF | socks1 = 191970 | pattern_la2= | pattern_b2 =_thinsidesonwhite | pattern_ra2= | pattern_so2= | pattern_sh2= | leftarm2 = CD0000 | body2 = 191970 | rightarm2 = CD0000 | shorts2 = FFFFFF | socks2 = 191970 }} '''Charrua Rugby Clube''' is a Brazilian [[rugby union]] club from the city of [[Porto Alegre]], [[Rio Grande do Sul]]. Charrua was founded in June 1, 2001 and they are the first [[rugby football|rugby]] club in the state of Rio Grande do Sul. == History == At the year of 2000, a group of friends, led by Nilson Taminato (former player of Rio Branco Rugby Clube) and Mauro Croitor, gathered to start practicing rugby, and on June 2, 2001, they officially founded the Charrua Rugby Clube. They first match was against [[Desterro Rugby Clube|Desterro]] and the first Charrua try was scored by Edson Taminato (Nilson's brother). The Club is affiliated to the [[Brazilian Rugby Confederation]]. The club's slogan, which uses local and informal terms, is "''Não 'tá morto quem peleia!''" ("''Not dead, he who fights''") and is shouted at the end of each practice, and the beginning and ending of their games. Their colors are a tribute to the city derby [[Grenal]]. Concerned about their social responsibilities to Charrua since its foundation, the club engages in actions such as the Campaign for Food and Sweaters. ==Presidential management== * Nilson Taminato (2001-2005) * Álvaro Montandón (2005-2007) * Rodrigo dos Reis (2007-2009) * Álvaro Montandón (2009-2011) * Uary Gondim (2011-current) == Main Titles == Males: * [[File:Mapa Regiao Sul do Brasil (somente).PNG|22px]] Championship in southern Brazil ''(Liga Sul)'': 1 time (2007) * [[File:Bandeira Estado RioGrandedoSul Brasil.svg|22px]] Championship of the state of Rio Grande do Sul ''(Campeonato Gaúcho)'': 2 times (2006, 2007) Females: * [[File:Mapa Regiao Sul do Brasil (somente).PNG|22px]] Championship in southern Brazil ''(Liga Sul)'': 3 times (2007, 2008, 2009) ==See also== * [[Charrúa people]] ==References== {{unreferenced|date=October 2016}} {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.charruarugby.com Charrua's website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080820062425/http://www.moradacharrua.com/ Pictures of the events of the club] {{Rugby union in Brazil}} [[Category:Brazilian rugby union teams]] {{Brazil-sport-stub}} {{rugbyunion-stub}}

{{seealso|Pull-up (exercise)}} [[File:Chin-ups.jpg|thumb|right|200px|A chin-up with palms facing chest, using open grip.]] The '''chin-up''' (also known as a '''chin''' or '''chinup''') is a [[Weight training|strength training]] exercise. People frequently do this exercise with the intention of strengthening muscles such as the [[latissimus dorsi]] and [[biceps]], which extend the shoulder and flex the elbow, respectively.{{cite web|url=http://pullupbar-chinupbar.com/articles/muscles-worked-in-a-pull-up/|title=Muscles worked in a Pull-Up|accessdate=10 July 2014|quote=During a Pull-Up the muscles that are mainly worked are those of the upper body and the arms.}} It is a form of [[pull-up (exercise)|pull-up]] in which the range of motion is established in relation to a person's chin. In the 1970s{{cite book |url=http://www.davidgentle.com/library/tensile/intro.htm |date=1972 |publisher=The Bodybuilding Center |location=[[Brampton]], Ontario, Canada |title=Tensile Contraction - Master Build |chapter=Back |pages=10, 15 |quote=14. Chinning The Bar (illus 15) Hang .. with your hands over the bar}}
{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mzWswaAaeEAC&pg=PA162 |page=162 |publisher=Bonnier Corporation |date=January 1972 |title=Popular Science Vol. 200, No. 1 |quote=45 Bodybuilding, Self-defense Courses .. Tensile Contraction - by mail .. The Bodybuilding Center, P.O. Box 146-PS-6 Brampton, Ontario, Canada}} and 1980s, the term chin-up not only included an overhand/pronated ("palms away") grip,{{cite book |last=Darden |first=Ellington |date=14 November 1984 |title=High-Intensity Bodybuilding |url=https://www.amazon.com/High-Intensity-Bodybuilding-Massive-Muscles-Fast/dp/0399511032 |location=New York |publisher=The Putnam Publishing Group |chapter=19. Wide, Wide Lats |pages=151–153 |isbn=0-399-51103-2 |quote=Behind neck '''chin''' up: .. Use an '''overhand''' grip.}}{{cite book |last1=Kennedy |first1=Robert |last2=Greenwood-Robinson |first2=Maggie |date=1987 |title=Built! The New Bodybuilding for Everyone! |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Built.html?id=fsuLAAAACAAJ |location=New York |publisher=The Putnam Publishing Group |pages=75–76 |isbn=0-399-51380-9 |chapter=Wide Grip Chins |quote=Take a wide '''overhand''' grip on the chinning bar and slowly hoist your body up until your chin is just above the bar.}} but some authors used it as the default meaning of the term,{{cite book |publisher=Health Culture Publications |url=http://www.davidgentle.com/library/super/index.html#p=8 |page=9 |title=The Super Routine |author=Russ |chapter=Wide Grip Chin Behind Neck}} with an underhand/supinated ("palms toward") grip called a "reverse" grip.{{cite book |last=Boff |first=Vic |date=1985 |title=Vic Boff's Body Builder's Bible For Men and Women |url=https://www.amazon.com/Boffs-Body-Builders-Bible-Women/dp/0668056304 |location=New York |publisher=Arco Publishing, Inc. |pages=100–103 |isbn=0-668-05630-4 |chapter=The Ever-Popular Chinning Bar |quote=Natural-Hands Grip: .. palms of your hands turned to the '''front''' .. Reverse-Hands Grip: .. palms of your hands facing your body .. The Neck '''Chin''' .. a wide '''natural'''-hands grip}} (paper edition, ISBN changes to 0-668-05625-8 for cloth edition){{cite book |last1=Kennedy |first1=Robert |last2=Ross |first2=Don |date=August 1988 |title=Muscleblasting! Brief and Brutal Shock Training |url=https://www.amazon.ca/Muscleblasting-Brief-Brutal-Shock-Training/dp/0806967587 |location=New York |publisher=Sterling Publishing Co., Inc. |pages=132 |isbn=0-8069-6758-7 |chapter=Appendix: The Exercises |quote=Chin Ups: Take a fairly wide grip on a chinning bar, palms '''away from''' you .. Close-Grip Chin-Ups: Hands are close together on the chinning bar, palms '''away from''' you .. Reverse Grip Chin-Ups: Use a curling grip (palms '''toward''' you)}} 2 photographs depicting an overhand (palms forward, pronated) grip and captions:
page 99 "Here Clare Furr shows impressively wide lats in her chin-ups."
page 132 "James DeMelo does an intense set of chin-ups" Even in the 2010s "chin-up" still includes palms-away lifting.{{cite book |last=Manocchia |first=Pat |date=2010 |title=Anatomy of Exercise (third printing) |url=https://www.amazon.ca/Anatomy-Exercise-Trainers-Inside-Workout/dp/1554073855 |location=Buffalo, New York |publisher=Firefly Books |page=83 |chapter=Chin-Up |quote=More Difficult: Use a wide-grip with .. your palms facing away from your body.}} The term "chin-up" is still regularly used refer to pulling using an overhand-grip.{{cite web |url=http://exrx.net/WeightExercises/LatissimusDorsi/BWChinup.html |title=Chin-up |quote=grasp bar with overhand wide grip |dead-url=no |archive-date=4 October 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091004011655/http://www.exrx.net/WeightExercises/LatissimusDorsi/BWChinup.html}}{{cite web |url=http://exrx.net/WeightExercises/LatissimusDorsi/WtChinup.html |title=Weighted Chin-up |quote=grasp bar with overhand wide grip |dead-url=no |archive-date=16 August 2001 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20010816092425/http://www.exrx.net/WeightExercises/LatissimusDorsi/WtChinup.html}}{{cite web |url=http://exrx.net/WeightExercises/LatissimusDorsi/AsChinup.html |title=Assisted (Wide Grip) Chin-up |quote=grasp bar with wide overhand grip |dead-url=no |archive-date=15 October 2001 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20011015091150/http://www.exrx.net/WeightExercises/LatissimusDorsi/AsChinup.html}} Both pull-ups and chin-ups are among the best{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} exercises for back and overall upper body conditioning. However, they target the muscles a bit differently. Both exercises will work the latissimus dorsi and biceps, but standard chin-ups—with an underhand grip—place more emphasis on the biceps. ==Etymology== A chin-up is named by bringing the chin up through space, specifically in relation to its position with the bar or other hand grips. This can be either touching the bar (more easily done by extending the neck, though that could be considered cheating) or by bringing the chin over the bar. This exercise is easier for males than females because of the male tendency to have stronger and larger biceps. This is usually achieved most easily with vertical forearms that are close to the body. For most, bringing the chin this high is most easily achieved with a [[supination|supinated]] (underhanded, palms-toward) grip. Due to this, the phrase "chin-up" has become associated with pulling with this type of grip. Some have delegated the term pull-up to refer to the [[pronation|pronated]] (overhanded, palms-away) grip. In spite of this, many refer to pull-ups with a pronated grip also as chin-ups, and the supine grip is still regularly called a pull-up. Some organizations such as the [[American Council on Exercise]] have adopted this new terminology, issuing statements such as: "''a chin-up differs from a pull-up in that the puller's hands are facing towards him or her in a chin-up, and away in a pull-up.''"{{cite web |url=http://www.acefitness.org/exerciselibrary/190/chin-ups |title=Chin-up |work=acefitness.org |publisher=[[American Council on Exercise]] |accessdate=27 March 2011}} Organizations such as the [[United States Marine Corps]], however, use the term pull-up interchangeably to refer to both the overhand and underhand grips.{{cite web |url=http://www.marines.mil/news/publications/Documents/MCO%20P6100.12%20W%20CH%201.pdf |title=USMC fitness PDF Chapter 2 |quote=a command will not mandate that Marines must use the overhand grip when executing pull-ups or flexed-arm hang |date=10 May 2002 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110522145154/http://www.marines.mil/news/publications/Documents/MCO%20P6100.12%20W%20CH%201.pdf |archivedate=22 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }} ==Form== A chin-up has a variety of different [[form (exercise)|form]]s.[http://www.exrx.net/WeightExercises/LatissimusDorsi/BWUnderhandChinup.html exrx.net defines Chin-Up]. The movement begins with the arms extended above the head, gripping a hold. It may be fixed, such as a [[chin-up bar]] or moving, such as [[gymnastic rings]] or rotating handles. The body is pulled up, with the bar approaching or touching the upper chest. A chin-up is considered complete based on a variety of criteria in relation to where the chin should be in respect to the bar, or in respect to the hand grips. The body is then lowered until the arms are straight but not in a lockout, and the exercise is generally repeated. Like any pull-up, chin-ups can be performed with a kip, where the legs and back flop around to aid the exercise, or from a dead hang, where the body is kept still. Performing the chin-up correctly can be tricky with a supinated grip, because of the natural tendency to do most of the work with the elbow flexors (largely biceps) rather than the shoulder extensors (largely lats). Initiating the pulling action with scapular depression may help avoid this problem. The exercise is most effective in stretching the working muscles when the body is lowered down to a full extension.{{cite web|url=http://build-muscle-gain-weight.com/back-muscles/how-to-perform-pull-ups-chin-ups.html|title=Build-muscle-gain-weight.com|author=|date=|website=build-muscle-gain-weight.com|accessdate=23 April 2018}} ==Grip and thumb position== A closed grip involves the thumb on the opposite side of the bar from the rest of the fingers.{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} ==Muscles targeted== Chin-ups, like most pull-ups, target the [[latissimus dorsi muscle]] of the back as a shoulder extensor, scapular downward rotator and scapular depressor, in bringing the spine to the humerus. This is assisted by elbow flexors ([[brachialis muscle|brachialis]], [[brachioradialis]], [[biceps brachii muscle|biceps brachii]]) which bring the humerus to the forearm. Chin-ups, unlike pull-ups, also highly target the biceps. That is one of the main differences between [[Pull-up (exercise)|pull-ups]] and chin-ups. The lat's functions are also assisted, both by shoulder extensors ([[teres major muscle|teres major]], posterior [[Deltoid muscle|deltoid]], [[infraspinatus muscle|infraspinatus]], [[teres minor muscle|teres minor]]), scapular downward rotators ([[rhomboid muscle|rhomboid]]s, [[levator scapulae muscle|levator scapulae]]), and scapular depressors (lower [[trapezius muscle|trapezius]] and [[pectoralis muscle|pectoralis]] muscles). Pulling higher with a narrow grip puts the focus on extension rather than adduction of the shoulder. If one leans back at the top of the movement, the focus is shifted somewhat towards scapular retraction and hyperextension. The weight of the legs and pelvis are borne by spinal ligaments and various muscles that flex or extend the spine. If the pelvis is tilted anterior and the legs brought behind, the [[erector spinae]] (with aid from the lats) bears more weight. If the pelvis is tilted posterior and the legs brought in front, the [[rectus abdominis]] (with aid from the psoas) bears more. ==Variations== *{{anchor|Sternum}}'''Sternal chin-ups''' (also called '''sternum chins''') — this variant employs a fuller range of motion at the top, raising beyond the chin and touching the sternum to the bar. The elbows are nearly directly below the shoulders this way. This requires adequate scapular depression. If leaning back (arching the spine) a sternum-up can be done that is not a chin-up, this shifts to requiring scapular retraction. Gironda-sternum-chins-2.png Gironda-sternum-chins-1.png *'''Weighted chin-ups''' — weight is added dangling from a dipping belt or via weighted belt or vest, ankle weights, chains, medicine ball between the knees, dumbbell between the feet or kettlebells on top of the feet. *'''One-arm chin-ups''' — one hand grips the bar and the other hand does not assist *'''One-hand chin-ups''' — One hand grips the bar while the other arm assists by grabbing the forearm of the arm hanging onto the bar. These require far less strength than a one-arm chin-up. *'''Spine chin-ups''' — in the [[supine position]], the arms are held perpendicular to the body as the grip the bar; instead of the chin, the chest is pulled towards the bar. This exercise is performed in the horizontal ([[Anatomical terms of location#Planes|transverse]]) plane, whereas other chin-up variations are performed in the vertical ([[Anatomical terms of location#Planes|coronal]]) plane. As a result, this variation recruits the [[trapezius]] and [[teres major]] muscles much more than a vertical chin-up would, and is more commonly known as the [[supine row]]. Advanced versions popular amongst gymnasts are performed completely off the ground in some type of [[front lever]]. *'''Harrison chin-ups''' — a term coined by powerlifter Dan Harrison, this technique is similar to a normal chin-up but with an arched spine to more effectively{{citation needed|date=July 2018}} target the latissimus dorsi and take strain off the biceps. Though it has become a recent phenomenon on the West Coast of the United States (especially with [[beach]]-goers), it has not yet gained widespread popularity. ==Training and performance== Specific training is needed in order to increase chin-ups performance. The performance can be measured in various ways: *number of repetitions without touching the floor *number of repetitions in a specified time interval (1/3/30 minutes, 1/6/12/24 hours) *number of repetitions with a total weight (body weight plus additional weight) Various organizations like [[Guinness World Records]] maintain lists of world records for chin-ups and [[Pull-up (exercise)|pull-ups]].{{cite web|url=http://www.recordholders.org/en/list/chinups.html|title=World Records for Chin-Ups and Pull-Ups|first=Ralf|last=Laue|date=|website=www.recordholders.org|accessdate=23 April 2018}} Both recordholders.org and [[Guinness World Records]] maintain that pull-ups use a pronated grip, while chin-ups use a supinated grip. == Chin-ups in fitness assessments == The chin-up exercise is used by uniformed services around the world to assess the physical fitness of its members. In order to be accepted into and remain in a particular service, a candidate may need to carry out a certain number of chin-ups to a prescribed technique. This number may vary with age and gender. *for US Rangers, the [[Ranger Physical Fitness Test]] requires candidates to complete at least six chin-ups in two minutes.{{cite web|url=http://www.military.com/military-fitness/army-special-operations/army-ranger-pft|title=Army Ranger PFT|author=|date=|website=military.com|accessdate=23 April 2018}} * for the [[United States Secret Service]], candidates are required to execute chin-ups with their arms fully extended in the downwards phase. No time limit is required. To achieve a 'fair' rating, male candidates need to complete seven chin-ups (if aged from 20 to 29), six (30 to 39), four (40 to 49) or two (over 50). Female candidates, irrespective of age, need to complete two chin-ups {{cite web|url=http://www.secretservice.gov/join/training/fitness|title=Physical Fitness Evaluation|author=|date=|website=www.secretservice.gov|accessdate=23 April 2018}}. * Australian navy clearance divers and special forces are required to complete six chin-ups (or 'heaves').http://www.defencejobs.gov.au/mobile/recruitment-centre/how-to-join/fitness-test.aspx * Canadian parachutists are required to demonstrate at least seven chin-upshttps://www.cfmws.com/en/AboutUs/PSP/DFIT/Fitness/Correspondence/Documents/Parachutist/PARACHUTIST%20PHYSICAL%20FITNESS%20TEST.pdf. == Chin-up bars == [[File:Gerald Quinn ChinUp Bar Clip Art.png|thumb|right]] Chin-up bars are [[playground]] equipment that were once ubiquitous on [[child]]ren's playgrounds. They are still important in the adult equivalent of a playground, the [[Par course]]. A chin-up bar is simply a smooth horizontal metal bar, often a [[plumbing|pipe]], held solidly above ground by a wooden or metal frame. Typical installations include 2 or 3 different heights of bars for people of different heights. Chin up bars are also a part of a home gym setup. Types of chin-up bars include doorway-mounted, wall-mounted, ceiling-mounted and free-standing. ==See also== {{Commons category|Pull-ups}} * [[Pull-up (exercise)]] * [[Pulldown exercise]] * [[Push up]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Commons category|Chin-ups}} {{Strength training exercises}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chin-Up}} [[Category:Bodyweight exercise]]

{{Infobox motorsport venue |Image = [[Image:Circuit Charade 1958 1988.png|250px]] |Image_caption = The original 8.055 km version of the track |Name = Circuit de Charade |Location = [[Saint-Genès-Champanelle]], [[Auvergne (province)|Auvergne]], [[France]] |Coordinates = {{coord|45|44|50|N|3|02|20|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |Time = [[Central European Time|GMT +1]] |Events = [[French Grand Prix]] (1965, 1969-1970, 1972)
[[French motorcycle Grand Prix]] (1959-1964, 1966-1967, 1972, 1974)
[[World Sportscar Championship]]
[[French Supertouring Championship]] |Layout1 = Modern Circuit |length_km = 3.975 |length_mi = 2.470 |Turns = 18 |Layout2 = Old Circuit |Length_km2 = 8.055 |Length_mi2 = 5.005 |Turns2 = 48 |Record_time2 = 2:53.9, 166.751 km/h |Record_driver2 = {{flagicon|NZL}} [[Chris Amon]] |Record_team2 = [[Equipe Matra Sports|Matra]] |Record_year2 = [[1972 French Grand Prix|1972]] |Record_class2 = [[Formula 1]] }} The '''Circuit de Charade''', also known as '''Circuit Louis Rosier''' and '''Circuit Clermont-Ferrand''', is a [[motorsport]] [[race track]] in [[Saint-Genès-Champanelle]] near [[Clermont-Ferrand]], [[France]].{{cite web|url=http://www.racingcircuits.info/europe/france/charade.html |title=Charade |publisher=racingcircuits.info |accessdate=31 March 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.speedhunters.com/2013/08/the-volcanic-rush-of-clermont-ferrand/ |title=The Volcanic Rush of Clermont Ferrand |publisher=speedhunters.com |accessdate=3 April 2017}} The circuit, built around the base of an extinct volcano, was known for its challenging layout which favored the most skillful drivers and motorcyclists. It hosted the [[French Grand Prix]] four times and the [[French motorcycle Grand Prix]] ten times. ==Circuit history== There had been local interest in motorsport racing beginning with proposals in 1908 for a race on a [[street circuit]], although the proposals were never enacted. Efforts were renewed after the Second World War when the President of the Sports Association of the Automobile Club of Auvergne, Jean Auchatraire, and accomplished racer [[Louis Rosier]] designed a course by adapting pre-existing roads around the [[Puy de Dôme]], an extinct [[volcano]] which dominated the city skyline.{{cite web|url=http://theracingline.net/racingcircuits/archives/Charade/history.html |title=A Brief History of Charade |publisher=theracingline.net |accessdate=4 April 2017}} Construction began in May 1957 and the first race was held in July 1958 when an [[Endurance racing (motorsport)|endurance race]] was won by [[Innes Ireland]] in a [[Lotus Eleven|Lotus 1100]], and a [[Formula Two]] race won by [[Maurice Trintignant]] in a [[Cooper T43]]. Originally, the 8.055 km (5.005-mi) long circuit was described as an even twistier and faster version of the [[Nürburgring]].{{cite web|url=http://en.espn.co.uk/france/motorsport/circuit/1285.html |title=Circuit Charade |publisher=espn.co.uk |accessdate=3 April 2017}} With a relentless number of sharp curves and elevation changes and with almost no discernible straights, the circuit was both feared and respected by competitors. The [[Sinuosity|sinuous]] track layout caused some drivers like [[Jochen Rindt]] in the [[1969 French Grand Prix]] to complain of [[motion sickness]], and wore open face helmets just in case. Despite the numerous curves, the track was relatively fast with [[Chris Amon]] setting the lap record in a [[Matra MS120]] with a 104 mph average during the [[1972 French Grand Prix]].{{cite web|url=https://www.formula1.com/en/results.html/1972/races/307/france/fastest-laps.html |title=1972 French Grand Prix fastest laps |publisher=formula1.com |accessdate=6 April 2017}} In his 1969 book ''Motor Cycle Racing'', Peter Carrick wrote:
The French Grand Prix circuit at Clermont Ferrand was seen to be in complete contrast to the lap at [[Autodromo Nazionale Monza|Monza]], when it was first used in 1959: the longest straight was 650 yards and a variety of really tight corners quickly demonstrated—or exposed—a rider's skill!Carrick, Peter ''Motor Cycle Racing'' Hamlyn Publishing 1969/70 p.91 {{ISBN|0 600 02506 3}} Accessed 2013-07-30
The venue first gained international prominence when it hosted the [[French motorcycle Grand Prix]] in [[1959 Grand Prix motorcycle racing season|1959]], won by [[John Surtees]] riding an [[MV Agusta]].{{cite web|url=http://www.motogp.com/en/Results+Statistics/1959/FRA/500cc |title=1959 French motorcycle Grand Prix |publisher=motogp.com |accessdate=3 April 2017}} The circuit would host the French motorcycle Grand Prix ten times between 1959 and [[1974 Grand Prix motorcycle racing season|1974]]. In 1959, [[Stirling Moss]] competed on the track for the first time and declared: "I don't know a more wonderful track than Charade". Also in 1959, [[Ivor Bueb]] winner of the [[1955 24 Hours of Le Mans]], died following a crash at the Charade Circuit. The death would mark the only driver fatality at the circuit. The only motorcyclist fatality occurred when Marcelin Herranz was killed on June 1, [[1963 Grand Prix motorcycle racing season|1963]] during the 250cc race of the French motorcycle Grand Prix.{{cite news | title=French Cycle Racer Killed in Crash |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=June 2, 1963 |page=C4}} The [[1964 Trophées d'Auvergne]] Formula 2 race podium was a sign of things to come: [[Denny Hulme]], [[Jackie Stewart]] and [[Jochen Rindt]] showed their skill before the circuit hosted its first [[Formula 1]] race when [[Jim Clark]] won the [[1965 French Grand Prix]] for [[Team Lotus]].{{cite web|url=http://www.formula2.net/F264_13.htm |title=GP d'Auvergne |publisher=Formula 2 |date= |accessdate=2014-02-04}}{{cite web|url=https://www.formula1.com/en/results.html/1965/races/228/france/race-result.html |title=1965 French Grand Prix |publisher=formula1.com |accessdate=3 April 2017}} In 1965, [[John Frankenheimer]] filmed a small part of his movie ''[[Grand Prix (1966 film)|Grand Prix]]'' in front of 3000 locals, who posed as race spectators watching actors like [[Yves Montand]] and [[Françoise Hardy]]. In total four Formula One French Grand Prix were held at Charade, in [[1965 French Grand Prix|1965]], [[1969 French Grand Prix|1969]], [[1970 French Grand Prix|1970]] and [[1972 French Grand Prix|1972]]. While the circuit's natural setting created conditions for a sinuous, challenging race course, it also created safety concerns due to the dark, volcanic rocks which fell from the mountain onto both sides of the track. The rocks meant that tire punctures were a perennial hazard at the Charade Circuit, as was shown when 10 competitors suffered punctures during the 1972 French Grand Prix. Drivers who skirted the track edge would send rocks flying in the middle of the road and into the path of pursuing competitors. In the most serious incident at the 1972 French Grand Prix, a stone thrown from [[Emerson Fittipaldi]]'s Lotus penetrated the helmet visor of [[Helmut Marko]], blinding him in the left eye and ending his racing career. The mountainous topography also left no room to provide safe [[run-off area]]s in the event of competitors losing control of their vehicles and unintentionally leaving the race course. The venue became increasingly shunned by international racing series as concerns about the public roads' dangerous nature rose. In 1971, the newly-built and much safer [[Circuit Paul Ricard]] held the French Grand Prix for the first time, before becoming the event's permanent home from 1973 to 1990, alternating the French Grand Prix with the Circuit [[Dijon-Prenois]].{{cite web|title=Paul Ricard Circuit History|url=https://www.circuitpaulricard.com/en/page-history-circuit-paul-ricard.html|website=www.circuitpaulricard.com|accessdate=15 June 2017}} It continued to host smaller motorsports competitions such as [[Formula 3]], [[sports car racing]], [[touring car racing]], [[rallying]] and [[hillclimbing]] as well as the Trophées d'Auverne. In 1980, three [[Motorsport marshal|track marshals]] were killed at a touring car race,{{cite web|url=http://www.motorsportmemorial.org/query.php?db=ct&q=circuit_a&n=57 |title=Car and truck fatalities by circuit |publisher=Motorsport Memorial |date= |accessdate=2012-05-28}} and in 1984 there was a drivers protest over track safety. Faced with increasing safety issues and with the natural topography preventing any chance of adding run-off areas, the final race on the original 8 km track was held on September 18, 1988. == Modernization == [[File:Circuit Charade 1989.png|thumb|right|The modern 3.975 km circuit, first used in 1989]] The [[Departmental councils (France)|General Council]] of [[Puy-de-Dôme]] recognized the importance of the race track to the local economy and financed the building of a new 3.975 km (2.47-mi) circuit utilising only the southern portion of the original, with a new link road completing the circuit.{{cite web|title=Circuit|url=http://www.charade.fr/infrastructures/circuit/|website=Circuit de Charade|publisher=Conseil départemental du Puy-de-Dôme|accessdate=23 September 2017}} The new Circuit de Charade opened in 1989 hosting national championship races in the [[1994 French Supertouring Championship]] and the 1998 [[FFSA GT Championship]]. Currently, the venue holds events such as [[track day]]s, driving courses as well as [[historic motorsport]] events. In 2000, the roads were closed to the public, with the track becoming a truly permanent facility with new [[Pit stop|pit garages]] and a widened pit lane. The original sections of the 8 km street circuit are still in use as public roadways. ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.charade.fr Official site] {{fr icon}} * [http://www.pour-charade.fr/ Official association site to save circuit] {{fr icon}} * [https://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&hl=en&q=Clermont-Ferrand,+France&ie=UTF8&om=1&z=16&ll=45.741667,3.032098&spn=0.006814,0.021629&t=k&iwloc=addr Satellite picture by Google Maps] (present layout; zoom out to see the old circuit) {{Formula One circuits}} {{MotoGP circuits}} {{World Sportscar Championship circuits}} [[Category:Formula One circuits]] [[Category:Grand Prix motorcycle circuits]] [[Category:Motorsport venues in France|Charade]] [[Category:Sports venues in Puy-de-Dôme]] [[Category:French Grand Prix]] [[Category:Sport in Clermont-Ferrand]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Puy-de-Dôme]] [[Category:Trophées d’Auvergne]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1958]]

{{Infobox venue |stadium_name = Fifth Third Field |nickname = |logo_image = |image = [[File:FifthThirdField.JPG|250px]] |caption = Main entrance to Fifth Third Field |location = 220 North Patterson Boulevard
[[Dayton, Ohio|Dayton, OH]] 45402 |coordinates = {{coord|39|45|51|N|84|11|6|W|type:landmark_region:US-OH|display=inline,title}} |broke_ground = April 26, 1999{{cite news |title=Ground Symbolically Broken For Stadium|first=Jim|last=Bebbington|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=DDNB&p_theme=ddnb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0F51BB8560BE6573&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|newspaper=[[Dayton Daily News]]|date=April 27, 1999|accessdate=September 16, 2011}} |built = March 4, 2000 |opened = April 23, 2000 |renovated = |expanded = |closed = |demolished = |owner = [[Dayton, Ohio|City of Dayton]] |operator = Palisades Arcadia Baseball LLC |surface = Grass |construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]23,500,000
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|23500000|2000}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) |architect = [[HNTB]]
Architects Associated, Inc. |project_manager = Construction Process Solutions Ltd. |structural engineer = Fink Roberts & Petrie, Inc.{{cite web|title=Athletic Facilities|url=http://www.frpinc.com/athletics.htm|publisher=Fink Roberts & Petrie, Inc.|accessdate=March 4, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130909002415/http://frpinc.com/athletics.htm|archivedate=September 9, 2013|df=}} |services engineer = Woolpert LLP{{cite web|title=Dayton Minor League Baseball Stadium|url=http://www.academic.umn.edu/layon/portfolio2000/online_media/eng%20minutes/webcam1.html|publisher=Woolpert LLP|accessdate=September 28, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160110173900/http://www.academic.umn.edu/layon/portfolio2000/online_media/eng%20minutes/webcam1.html|archive-date=2016-01-10|dead-url=no|df=}} |general_contractor = Danis Building Construction Company{{cite web|title=Danis Building Construction Company|url=http://www.archiplanet.org/wiki/Danis_Building_Construction_Company,_Dayton,_Ohio,_USA|work=Archiplanet|accessdate=September 28, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111213140800/http://www.archiplanet.org/wiki/Danis_Building_Construction_Company%2C_Dayton%2C_Ohio%2C_USA|archive-date=2011-12-13|dead-url=yes|df=}} |main_contractors = |former_names = |tenants = [[Dayton Dragons]] (2000–present) |seating_capacity = 7,230 seats
~1,000 lawn area |record_attendance = 9,507 (June 19, 2009){{cite web|title=Record Crowd Sees Votto Homer, But Dragons Lose|first=Tom|last=Nichols|url=http://www.milb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20090620&content_id=5440970&vkey=news_t459&fext=.jsp&sid=t459|publisher=Minor League Baseball|date=June 20, 2009|accessdate=March 4, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160110173900/http://www.milb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20090620&content_id=5440970&vkey=news_t459&fext=.jsp&sid=t459|archive-date=2016-01-10|dead-url=no|df=}} | dimensions = Left field – 320 ft (98 m)
Center field – 400 ft (122 m)
Right field – 320 ft (98 m) }} '''Fifth Third Field''' is a [[minor league baseball]] stadium in [[Dayton, Ohio]], which is the home of the [[Dayton Dragons]], a [[Midwest League]] team and a Single-A affiliate of the nearby [[Cincinnati Reds]]. The naming rights are owned by [[Fifth Third Bank]], based in [[Cincinnati]]. In 2011, the Dragons broke the all-time professional sports record for most consecutive sellouts by selling out the stadium for the 815th consecutive game, breaking the record formerly held by the [[Portland Trail Blazers]].{{cite web|title=Dragons Break All-Time Sports Sell-Out Record|url=http://www.milb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20110709&content_id=21669014&vkey=pr_t459&fext=.jsp&sid=t459|publisher=Minor League Baseball|date=July 9, 2011|accessdate=July 10, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150723085318/http://www.milb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20110709&content_id=21669014&vkey=pr_t459&fext=.jsp&sid=t459|archive-date=2015-07-23|dead-url=no|df=}}{{cite news|title=Dayton Dragons Break Sellout Record |url=http://www.whiotv.com/news/news/dayton-dragons-break-sellout-record/nDLZ8/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130209055154/http://www.whiotv.com/news/news/dayton-dragons-break-sellout-record/nDLZ8/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 9, 2013 |work=[[WHIO-TV|WHIO]] |location=Dayton |date=July 19, 2011 |accessdate=March 4, 2014 }} The park has a total capacity of 8,200 people and opened in 2000. With two-deck seating and large [[Luxury box|skyboxes]], some compare it to [[Triple-A (baseball)|Triple-A]] fields.{{cite web|title=Fifth Third Field|first=Brian|last=Merzbach|url=http://www.ballparkreviews.com/dayton/dayton.htm|work=Ballpark Reviews|accessdate=March 4, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131211145706/http://www.ballparkreviews.com/dayton/dayton.htm|archive-date=2013-12-11|dead-url=no|df=}} ==History== The [[Dayton Dragons]] played their first baseball game at Fifth Third Field on April 27, 2000. In attendance was [[Cincinnati Reds]] Hall of Famer [[Johnny Bench]], who caught the ceremonial first pitch. In their inaugural season, the Dragons managed to sell-out every home game of the 2000 season before the season even started. Fifth Third Field has hosted the [[Midwest League]] All Star Game twice: in 2001 and 2013. In 2005, 2007, and 2009, the venue hosted the [[Atlantic 10 Conference Baseball Tournament]]. In 2005, [[Rhode Island Rams baseball|Rhode Island]] won the tournament, in 2007, [[Charlotte 49ers baseball|Charlotte]] won, and in 2009 [[Xavier Musketeers baseball|Xavier]] won.{{cite web|title=Atlantic 10 Conference Baseball Record Book |url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/atl10/sports/m-basebl/auto_pdf/2011-12/misc_non_event/Baseball_Records_thru2011.pdf |publisher=Atlantic 10 Conference |accessdate=February 16, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65VOAPx1L?url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/atl10/sports/m-basebl/auto_pdf/2011-12/misc_non_event/Baseball_Records_thru2011.pdf |archivedate=February 16, 2012 |pages=12–3 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ===2011 field renovation=== In the 2011–2012 offseason, a new Kentucky Blue Grass playing surface was installed at Fifth Third Field as well as new drainage and irrigation systems. ===2014-2015 video enhancements=== In 2014, over $1.2 million was spent upgrading Fifth Third Field's entertainment control room and adding HD cameras throughout. In 2015, the existing video board was replaced in the off-season with a new 2,054 foot 13HD video board that was three times brighter than the previous board, twice the height and 2½ times the width. Described as featuring the clearest picture ever used on any board in a Minor League Baseball stadium, the board, at the time of installation, was the tallest and widest in a single A facility and in the top five in terms of size for any Minor League Baseball stadium. As of 2015, only three out of 30 Major League Baseball stadiums sported a board of this type.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cincinnati.com/story/redsblog/2015/02/11/dayton-dragons-giant-high-definition-video-board/23237821/|title=Dayton Dragons getting giant HD video board|first=David|last=Clark|date=February 11, 2015|accessdate=June 4, 2015|publisher=Cincinnati.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160110173900/http://www.cincinnati.com/story/redsblog/2015/02/11/dayton-dragons-giant-high-definition-video-board/23237821/|archive-date=2016-01-10|dead-url=no|df=}} ==Facts and figures== * Voted as one of the top ten hottest [[Ticket (admission)|tickets]] to get in all of professional sports by [[Sports Illustrated]].{{cite news|title=Sports Illustrated Rating|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/multimedia/photo_gallery/0704/gallery.hottest.tickets/content.10.html|work=Sports Illustrated|date=April 1, 2007|accessdate=March 4, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020030602/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/multimedia/photo_gallery/0704/gallery.hottest.tickets/content.10.html|archive-date=2012-10-20|dead-url=no|df=}} * The Dayton Dragons' series of 815 consecutive sellouts surpassed the [[Portland Trail Blazers]] for the longest sellout streak across all professional sports in the U.S.{{cite web|title=Dayton Dragons Set Consecutive Sellout Record|first=Tony|last=Meale|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20110710&content_id=21677950&vkey=news_mlb&c_id=mlb|publisher=[[Major League Baseball Advanced Media]]|date=July 10, 2011|accessdate=March 4, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102200205/http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20110710&content_id=21677950&vkey=news_mlb&c_id=mlb|archive-date=2014-01-02|dead-url=no|df=}}{{cite news |title=Dayton Dragons All Time Professional Sellout Streak|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/nationals/dayton-dragons-break-record-with-815th-straight-sellout-surpassing-mark-set-by-trail-blazers/2011/07/09/gIQAhzn85H_story.html|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]date=July 9, 2011|accessdate=July 10, 2011}} {{Dead link|date=April 2014|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} * Highest single-season attendance: 593,633 (2004, a [[Midwest League]] Record){{cite web|title=Past Attendance|url=http://web.minorleaguebaseball.com/about/page.jsp?ymd=20061214&content_id=148639&vkey=about_l118&fext=.jsp&sid=l118|publisher=Minor League Baseball|date=December 14, 2006|accessdate=March 4, * Fifth Third Field has 7,320 stadium-style seats.{{cite web|title=About Fifth Third Field|url=http://web.minorleaguebaseball.com/team1/page.jsp?ymd=20090308&content_id=520865&vkey=team1_t459&fext=.jsp&sid=t459|publisher=Minor League Baseball|date=March 8, 2009|accessdate=March 4, * The ballpark contains 1,400 club seats,{{cite web|title=Baseball Minor League to Dbq|url=http://weblink.cityofdubuque.org/WebLink8/1/doc/28063/Page63.aspx|publisher=City of Dubuque|accessdate=March 4, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160110173900/http://weblink.cityofdubuque.org/WebLink8/1/doc/28063/Page63.aspx|archive-date=2016-01-10|dead-url=no|df=}} 29 suites, and 3 party decks * The stadium stands on the site of a former [[Delco Electronics]] plant.{{cite news|title=For One Minor League Baseball Team, Never an Empty Seat|first=George|last=Vecsey|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/03/sports/baseball/for-one-minor-league-baseball-team-never-an-empty-seat.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 2, 2011|accessdate=April 21, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151016193407/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/03/sports/baseball/for-one-minor-league-baseball-team-never-an-empty-seat.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|archive-date=2015-10-16|dead-url=no|df=}} ==Amenities== Fifth Third Field has contracted with [[Donatos Pizza]] to offer individual cheese and pepperoni pizzas at Fifth Third Field. Apart from Donatos Pizza, Fifth Third Field has contracted with [[Cold Stone Creamery]] to offer hand dipped ice cream available at a free standing cart on the third base side of the stadium as well as individual ice cream cups available at most concession stands. Along with the contracted food, many [[nonprofit]] organizations including [[church (building)|churches]], [[fraternal organizations]] and [[schools]] operate the concessions stands.{{cite news |title=Groups Work Dragons Games to Raise Money|first=Marc|last=Katz|url=http://www.daytondailynews.com/news/dayton-news/134640.html|newspaper=[[Dayton Daily News]]|date=June 15, 2009|accessdate=September 28, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604031449/http://www.daytondailynews.com/news/dayton-news/134640.html|archivedate=June 4, 2011}} In 2009, The [[People for Ethical Treatment of Animals]] (PETA) rated Fifth Third Field one of the most [[vegetarian]]-friendly minor league ballparks in the United States.{{cite news |title=Fifth Third Field Among Most Vegetarian-Friendly|url=http://dayton.bizjournals.com/dayton/stories/2009/06/08/daily3.html?ed=2009-06-08&ana=e_du_pap|newspaper=[[American City Business Journals|Dayton Business Journal]]|date=June 8, 2009|accessdate=March 4, 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{s-start-collapsible|header={{s-sta|et}}}} {{succession box |title=Home of the [[Dayton Dragons]] |years=[[2000 in baseball|2000]] – present |before=[[Marinelli Field]] |after=Current {{succession box | title = Host of the

revision.text:
Game Bike is an interactive fitness bike that requires the user to exercise in order to play their [[video games]]. The user must pedal the bike in order for the character to accelerate and must turn the handlebars to steer. The Game Bike allows users to control the character in their game while getting [[exercise]].
==History== Game Bike is the name of an interactive fitness device first invented and patented by Edward H. (Ted) Parks, M.D. in 2000.<ref>U.S. Patent # 6,126,571</ref> Dr. Parks sold the rights to his patent to Cateye Co Ltd, a Japanese company with expertise in electronic bicycle accessories, such as bike lights and speedometers. Cateye's initial embodiment of Parks' design used a traditional bicycle attached to what they referred to as their GB100 system. The front tire was placed into a turn style platform that was used to read direction. Sensors were placed of the rear wheel which was mounted in a bicycle trainer to measure the speed. Cateye Co Ltd. first started production of the Game Bike in the GB100 form.
The project was then handled by a group in New Jersey that redesigned the product to be a single package incorporated into a stand-alone indoor exercise bike. The GB200 was born. An immediate need for a commercial version was soon covered by the introduction of the popular GB-300 Game Bike.
Late in 2008 Cateye Co Ltd. stopped all international distribution of the fitness line. Game Bike Production was then done by Source Distributors Inc. out of [[Dallas, Texas]]. Source Distributors produced the bike and made modifications to the unit to improve the controller serviceability. The Game Bike is a popular product within the school and YMCA markets. Thousands of bikes were sold in since the start of 2003.
Game Bike is now owned by Hudson Fitness LLC. Game Bike is currently available and Hudson Fitness LLC continues supporting the Game Bike service.
==Compatible titles== Compatible titles include: Any speed-based video game for PS2/PS3/Game Cube/Xbox
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|www.gamebike.com}} {{404|date=August 2016}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070930181612/http://gamepolitics.com/2006/12/23/gamebike-proves-there-is-more-to-healthy-gaming-than-ddr/ GameBike Proves There is More to Healthy Gaming than Just DDR] at [[GamePolitics.com]]

(Deutschland-Preis) |image = |caption = |location = Hoppegarten Racecourse
[[Hoppegarten]], [[Germany]] |inaugurated = 1888 |race type = [[Flat racing|Flat]] / [[Thoroughbred]] |sponsor = [[Longines]] |website = [http://www.hoppegarten.com/ Hoppegarten] |distance = 2,400 metres (1½ miles) |surface = Turf |track = Right-handed |qualification = Three-years-old and up |weight = 55 kg (3yo); 60 kg (4yo+)
'''Allowances'''
2 kg for [[Filly|fillies]] and [[mare]]s |purse = €175,000 ''(2016)''
'''1st:''' €110,000 }} The '''Grosser Preis von Berlin''', formerly known as the '''Deutschland-Preis''', is a [[Conditions races|Group 1]] [[Flat racing|flat]] [[Horse racing|horse race]] in [[Germany]] open to [[thoroughbred]]s aged three years or older. It is run at [[Hoppegarten]] over a distance of 2,400 metres (about 1½ miles), and it is scheduled to take place each year in July or August. ==History== The event was established in 1888, and it was originally staged at Hoppegarten as the Grosser Preis von Berlin. It was initially contested over 2,000 metres, and was extended to 2,200 metres in 1897. It was transferred to [[Grunewald]] and increased to 2,400 metres in 1909. A new distance of 2,600 metres was introduced in 1927. The race returned to Hoppegarten in 1934, and it was renamed the Grosser Preis der Reichshauptstadt in 1937. From this point it was run over 2,400 metres, and it reverted to 2,600 metres in 1943. The event switched to [[Düsseldorf]] and was renamed the Grosser Preis von Nordrhein-Westfalen in 1947. That year's running was over 2,400 metres, and it returned to 2,600 metres in 1948. Its current period over 2,400 metres began in 1965. The present race grading system was introduced in Germany in 1972, and the Grosser Preis von Nordrhein-Westfalen was classed at Group 1 level. Its original title, the Grosser Preis von Berlin, was restored in 1977. The event became known as the Deutschland-Preis in 1996. It was held at [[Horner Rennbahn|Hamburg]] and merged with the [[Hansa-Preis]] in 2010. It returned to Hoppegarten as the Grosser Preis von Berlin in 2011. ==Records== '''Most successful horse (3 wins):''' * Ticino – ''1942, 1943, 1944'' * Mercurius – ''1963, 1964, 1965'' ---- '''Leading [[jockey]] (8 wins):''' * Otto Schmidt – ''Ossian (1921), Augias (1923, 1924), Elritzling (1939), Ticino (1942, 1943, 1944), Niederländer (1950)'' ---- '''Leading [[Horse trainer|trainer]] (10 wins):''' * George Arnull – ''Weissdorn (1925), Mah Jong (1927), Oleander (1928, 1929), Alba (1930), Wolkenflug (1932), Blinzen (1934), Sturmvogel (1935, 1936), Schwarzgold (1940)'' : ''(note: the trainers of some of the early winners are unknown)'' ---- '''Leading owner (22 wins):''' * Gestüt Schlenderhan – ''Dorn (1892), Signor (1903), For Ever (1909), Dolomit (1912), Majestic (1913), Wallenstein (1922), Weissdorn (1925), Mah Jong (1927), Oleander (1928, 1929), Alba (1930), Wolkenflug (1932), Blinzen (1934), Sturmvogel (1935, 1936), Schwarzgold (1940), Agio (1958), Alpenkönig (1970), Lombard (1971, 1972), Arratos (1973), Adlerflug (2008)'' {{clear}} ==Winners since 1970== {| class = "sortable" | border="1" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; font-size:90%" |- bgcolor="#77dd77" align="center" ! {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox venue | name = Huish Park | image = [[Image:External Huish Park.jpg|300px]] | caption = External view of Main Stand in March 2007 | fullname = Huish Park Stadium | location = [[Yeovil]], [[Somerset]], England | coordinates = {{coord|50|57|0.94|N|2|40|25.84|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = UK England | pushpin_map_caption = Location of Huish Park | built = 1989–1990 | opened = 4 August 1990 | renovated = | expanded = | owner = Huish Park Stadium Partnership Ltd | operator = Yeovil Town | surface = Grass | cost = [[Pound sterling|£]]3.5 million | architect = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 9,565 (5,212 seated){{cite news |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/clubs/20100801/yeovil-town_2293500_692102 |title=Yeovil Town |publisher=The Football League |accessdate=6 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130312002105/http://www.football-league.co.uk/clubs/20100801/yeovil-town_2293500_692102 |archivedate=12 March 2013 |df=dmy-all }} | record_attendance = 9,527 [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]] vs. [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] | dimensions = {{convert|115|x|72|yd|m|0}} | tenants = [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town Football Club]] (1990–present)
[[Yeovil Town L.F.C.|Yeovil Town Ladies Football Club]] (2016–present) }} '''Huish Park''' is a [[Association football|football]] [[stadium]] located in [[Yeovil]], Somerset, England. The stadium has been home to [[Yeovil Town F.C.]] since its completion in 1990, following their relocation from [[Huish Athletic Ground|Huish]]. Huish Park has a capacity of 9,565 (of which two stands are all-seated, totalling 5,212 seats) with terraces behind each of the goals. ==History== In January 1985, Yeovil started negotiations to sell the [[Huish Athletic Ground]] and move to a new stadium in the Houndstone area of [[Yeovil]] on the site of an old army camp. Negotiations commenced between the club and Bartlett Construction regarding moving from Huish to a new site at Houndstone Camp, with the first meeting taking place on 12 November 1985 when an offer of £1.3m was made for the Huish site. Following further meetings and more detailed plans being studied the offer was raised to over £2m early in 1986, when the directors agreed in principle for the move to go ahead. A company, Collier & Madge, who specialised in buying and selling supermarket sites was engaged to advise the club and to ensure the best possible price was obtained. On 15 December 1986 the club was informed by its advisors, Collier and Madge, that the offer of £2.4m now on the table was about as much as they could hope to receive. It was revealed that the new proposed site for the club was 20.75 acres of [[Freehold (law)|freehold land]] at Houndstone Camp with a further 4.2 acres being made available on a 999-year lease. The directors agreed in principle to the deal and [[Tesco]] were insisting that contracts should be exchanged by the end of March 1987 with the building contractors having vacant possession by July 1988. Further discussions took place with [[South Somerset|South Somerset District Council]] regarding developing the new site for recreational use, and they set aside money to purchase the land. At an [[extraordinary general meeting]] held on 25 August 1987, shareholders gave the go-ahead to "conclude negotiations with F. R. Bartlett Limited for the sale of Huish and to negotiate the development of the Houndstone site". The voting was 14,431 for and 1,356 against, giving a majority of 13,075, representing 91% in favour. On 15 September 1987, the Public Inquiry began which was to delay the proposed move for a long time; two days later the final agreement was signed. On 21 March 1989, and after a wait of just over 20 months, the result of the Public Inquiry was made known. The Department of the Environment granted planning permission to develop Huish, therefore the move to Houndstone was now on. The first work at the new ground got underway in May 1989 when boreholes were drilled. A month later it was revealed that the cost of the new development had risen to £3.5m and that Bartletts had come forward with a further £400,000 bringing the total for the sale of Huish to £2.8m. On Sunday 1 April 1990, over 500 supporters viewed the new stadium at Houndstone, and it was announced the new stadium would be called '''Huish Park'''. The new Huish Park Stadium was opened with a [[Exhibition game|friendly]] against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on 4 August 1990, ending in a 2–1 defeat in front of a crowd of 5,093. The first competitive match followed on 18 August 1990 with a [[Football Conference]] match against [[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United]], the 2–0 win for Yeovil resulted in Mickey Spencer scoring Yeovil's first competitive goal at the new ground. The first season at the new ground resulted in an average attendance of 2,639, an increase of 17.6%,{{cite web |url=http://www.ciderspace.co.uk/ASP/statistics/average_attendances.asp |title=Yeovil Town Average Attendances |publisher=Ciderspace |accessdate=21 December 2011 }} and the season finished with an U18 international match between [[England national under-18 football team|England]] and [[Wales national under-18 football team|Wales]] attracting a bumper 6,153 crowd. The [[1999–2000 in English football|1999–2000 season]] saw a proposal for the erection of a roof over the home terrace. The work eventually took place in early 2001, with the roof being completed for the match against [[Rushden & Diamonds F.C.|Rushden & Diamonds]] with a then record crowd of 8,868.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2001/apr/23/match.sport12 |title=No resolution at Yeovil summit |publisher=The Guardian |date=23 April 2001 }} Following Yeovil's promotion to [[the Football League]], crowds increased by 30% to an average of 6,197 in the [[2003–04 in English football|2003–04 season]], and on 25 April 2008 Yeovil's match against [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] saw the record attendance at the ground of 9,527.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/7358705.stm |title=Yeovil Town 0–1 Leeds United |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 April 2008 }} ==Stands== The ground is made up of four stands: * '''Tamburino Stand''' (Main Stand), is a cantilevered covered single tiered stand that is all-seated. The stand has executive boxes running across its back and bar areas, the dug outs and players' tunnel, a small simple electric scoreboard, and it houses the ticket office and club shop. * '''[[Screwfix]] Community Stand''' (East Stand), similar to the Main Stand in style with a Press Box beneath its roof. * '''[[Thatchers Cider|Thatchers Gold]] Stand''' (Home Terrace), similar style covered cantilevered terrace for home fans. * '''Radio Cabs Stand''' (Away Terrace), smaller uncovered terrace with a large electric scoreboard behind. ==Attendances== [[Image:Huish Park attendances.png|right|thumb|300px|Average and highest attendances at the ground since it was opened in the [[1990-91 in English football|1990–91 season]].]] The five highest attendances at Huish Park are: {| class="wikitable sortable" width="600px" |- ! Date ! Competition ! Opposition ! Attendance |- | 25 April 2008 | [[Football League One|League One]] | [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] | 9,527 |- | 4 January 2004 | [[FA Cup]] | [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] | 9,348 |- | 4 January 2015 | FA Cup | [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] | 9,264 |- | 26 January 2018 | FA Cup | Manchester United | 9,195 |- | 31 December 2005 | League One | [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] | 9,178 |} Source:{{cite web |url=http://www.ciderspace.co.uk/ASP/statistics/huish_park_top_attendances.asp |title=Huish Park Top Attendances |publisher=Ciderspace |accessdate=20 December 2011 }} ==International games== The stadium has been used for the following international games: * 22 May 1991 [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] Vs [[Wales national under-18 football team|Wales U18]] (3–0) * 17 May 1992 [[England women's national football team|England women]] Vs [[Iceland women's national football team|Iceland women]] (4–0) * 16 November 1993 [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] Vs [[France national under-18 football team|France U18]] (3–3) * 23 April 1996 [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] Vs [[Scotland national under-18 football team|Scotland U18]] (3–0) * 15 September 1999 [[England women's national football team|England women]] Vs [[France women's national football team|France women]] (0–1) * 24 April 2002 [[England C national football team|England Semi-Pro]] Vs Netherlands Semi-Pro * 27 March 2007 [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] Vs [[Netherlands national under-18 football team|Netherlands U18]] (4–1) * 15 October 2009 [[England national under-16 football team|England U16]] Vs [[Wales national under-16 football team|Wales U16]] (1–0) * 25 March 2011 England Schools U16 Vs Wales Schools U16 (1–0) * 20 November 2014 [[England national under-16 football team|England U16]] Vs [[Scotland national under-16 football team|Scotland U16]] (2–1) ==Future development== In March 2011, Yeovil Town announced plans for a 3,500 seat stand to replace the current Away Terrace,{{cite news |url=http://www.ytfc.net/page/NewDevelopments/0,,10673~2321179,00.html |title=YTFC Plan Major New Developments |publisher=Yeovil Town FC |date=21 March 2011 }} in conjunction with the training pitches being redeveloped into retail land creating over 300 jobs in partnership with Chris Dawson, owner of [[the Range Home and Leisure]].{{cite news |url=http://www.fcbusiness.co.uk/news/article/newsitem=1054/title=yeovil+town+announce+stadium+upgrade+plans |title=Yeovil Town announce stadium upgrade plans |publisher=FC Business |date=24 March 2011 }} Following public consultation in late-November 2011 the plans for a new stand have dropped off the agenda with the retail development continuing as a new food store.{{cite news |url=http://www.ytfc.net/page/NewDevelopments/0,,10673~2533446,00.html |title=Development Plans Update – Dec 1st |publisher=Yeovil Town FC |date=1 December 2011 }} ==Gallery== Image:Yeovil Town Football Ground - geograph.org.uk - 808807.jpg|View looking towards the Main Stand Image:Yeovil Town Football Ground - geograph.org.uk - 808813.jpg|External view of the East Stand Image:Huish Park.jpg|View across the pitch from the Home Terrace Image:Huish Park, September 2007.jpg|View across the pitch from the East Stand Image:Yeovil Town Away Terrace.jpg|View of the Away Terrace Image:Yeovil Town FC, View across the pitch - geograph.org.uk - 1722486.jpg|Yeovil celebrating their [[Football Conference]] triumph with East Stand in the background ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.ytfc.net/club/huishpark.aspx Huish Park] at official Yeovil FC site *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110724124925/http://www.footballgroundguide.com/yeovil_town/ Footballground Guide Article] *[http://stadiumdb.com/stadiums/eng/huish_park Stadium pictures] {{Commons category|Huish Park}} {{Yeovil Town F.C.}} {{Football League Two venues}} [[Category:Yeovil Town F.C.]] [[Category:Football venues in England]] [[Category:Yeovil]] [[Category:Sports venues in Somerset]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1990]] [[Category:English Football League venues]]

{{other uses|Huracan (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = Huracán FC | image = [[File:Huracán F.C. logo.png|150px]]| fullname = Sportivo Huracán Fútbol Club | nickname = ''El Hura, Tricolor del Paso'' | founded = 1 August 1954 | ground = [[Parque Pedro Ángel Bossio]],
[[Montevideo]], [[Uruguay]]| capacity = 2,000 | chairman = Jorge Álvarez | manager = Juan Alberto Quintela | mgrtitle = Coach | league = [[Uruguayan Segunda División Amateur|Segunda B Nacional]] | season = 2014–15 | position = 8th | shirtsupplier = | pattern_la1=_redborder|pattern_b1=_whitehalf2|pattern_ra1=_redborder| leftarm1=FFFFFF|body1=0000FF|rightarm1=0000FF|shorts1=FF0000|socks1=FF0000| pattern_la2=_blueborder|pattern_b2=|pattern_ra2=_blueborder| leftarm2=FF0000|body2=FF0000|rightarm2=FF0000|shorts2=FF0000|socks2=FF0000| pattern_la3=_whiteborder|pattern_b3=|pattern_ra3=_whiteborder| leftarm3=0000FF|body3=0000FF|rightarm3=0000FF|shorts3=ffffff|socks3=ffffff| }} '''Sportivo Huracán Fútbol Club''', usually known simply as '''Huracán''' and sometimes called as '''Huracán del [[Paso de la Arena]]''', is an [[Uruguay]]an [[football (soccer)|football]] club based in [[Montevideo]]. It was founded in 1954. ==History== Huracán Fútbol Club was founded on August 1, 1954 through the merger of two clubs composed mainly of young students: the "Club Atlético Charrúa" and "La Esquinita Football Club". The new team's name was inspired by a former club "Huracán" that participated in Uruguayan leagues during early of 20th century. Colors adopted from [[Club Nacional de Football]], because Huracán founders were fans of this Uruguayan giant. Club was affiliated to the [[Uruguayan Football Association|AUF]] in 1962. Their highest performance was in 1991, when Huracán fought for promotion to [[Uruguayan Primera División]]. However, in the final game at home they lost 0:4 to [[Liverpool Fútbol Club|Liverpool]], while their opponents [[Club Atlético River Plate (Uruguay)|River Plate]] won in [[La Paz (Uruguay)|La Paz]] against [[Club Oriental de Football|Oriental]], achieving promotion. In 2010 Huracán achieved promotion from Segunda División Amateur (third level) and returns to the Professional Second Division of Uruguay. From May to August 2011 Huracán merged with [[Club Atlético Torque]] and named ''Huracán Torque'', but later this merge was dissolved. Huracán Torque never played in official games.[http://www.huracanfc.com/?p=227 Se disolvió la fusión Huracán Torque F.C.] ==Titles== * [[Segunda División Amateur de Uruguay]] (3): 1983, 1990, 2009/10 * [[Primera "D" (Uruguay)]]4th division in 1972–1978 (1): 1978 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Commonscat-inline|Sportivo Huracán Fútbol Club}} *[http://huracanfutbolclub.com.uy/ Official site of Huracán Fútbol Club (Montevideo)] {{Segunda División Uruguay}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Huracan Futbol Club}} [[Category:Football clubs in Uruguay]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1954]] [[Category:Sport in Montevideo]] [[Category:1954 establishments in Uruguay]] {{Uruguay-footyclub-stub}}

{{color box|#00529c|border=darkgray}} {{Color box|#00a651|border=darkgray}} {{Color box|#f5c62f|border=darkgray}} | president = Aleksandar Obajdin | coach = Nenad Stefanović | championships = | website = {{URL|http://www.kkzemun.ksb.rs/|kkzemun.ksb.rs}} }} '''Košarkaški klub Zemun''' ({{lang-sr-cyrl|Кошаркашки клуб Земун}}), commonly referred to as '''KK Zemun Fitofarmacija''' for sponsorship reasons, is a men's professional [[basketball]] [[Sports club|club]] based in [[Belgrade]], [[Serbia]]. They are currently competing in the [http://lige.kss.rs/seniori/2-muska-liga/ Second men league of Serbia (Serbia)] (2nd-tier).] Since 2015, the club has been organizing the ''Dado Trophy of Zemun'' in a honor of their former player and coach Vladimir "Dado" Arnautović.{{cite web |title=Zemun organizuje turnir u čast Vladimira Dade Arnautovića |url=https://sport.blic.rs/kosarka/domaca-kosarka-i-aba/zemun-organizuje-turnir-u-cast-vladimira-dade-arnautovica/ncgme7d |website=sport.blic.rs |accessdate=16 June 2018}}{{cite web |title=MEMORIJALNI TURNIR Zemunci igraju u Dadinu čast |url=https://sport.blic.rs/kosarka/domaca-kosarka-i-aba/memorijalni-turnir-zemunci-igraju-u-dadinu-cast/nlr63vk |website=sport.blic.rs |accessdate=16 June 2018}} ==Sponsorship naming== KK Zemun has had several denominations through the years due to its sponsorship: {| |- style="vertical-align: top;" | *'''Zemun Lasta''': ?-? *'''Zemun Fitofarmacija''': 2017–present |} == Players == {{main|Category:KK Zemun players}} == Coaches == {{main|Category:KK Zemun coaches}} ==Trophies and awards== ===Trophies=== * '''[[First Regional Basketball League (Serbia)|First Regional League (Central Division)]]''' ([[Serbian basketball league system|3rd-tier]]) ** '''Winners (1)''': 2017–18 == Notable players == * {{flagicon|SCG}} [[Milan Dozet]] ;Youth selections * {{flagicon|SCG}} [[Novica Veličković]] * {{flagicon|SRB}} [[Vuk Vulikić]] * {{flagicon|SRB}} [[Marko Pecarski]] == See also == * [[KK Mladost Zemun]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.kkzemun.ksb.rs/ Official website] {{sr icon}} * [https://www.srbijasport.net/klub/4360-zemun/rez Profile] at srbijasport.net {{sr icon}} * [http://basketball.eurobasket.com/team/Serbia/KK-Zemun/4265 Profile] at eurobasket.com {{Men's Basketball Teams in Serbia}} [[Category:Zemun]] [[Category:Basketball teams in Serbia|Zemun]] {{Serbia-sport-stub}} {{Europe-basketball-team-stub}}

{{unreferenced|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox ski jumping hill | hill_name = Kløvsteinbakken | nickname = | image = | caption = | location = | city = [[Meldal]] | country = [[Norway]] | opened = 1946 | renovated = 1965, 1981, 1997, 2002 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | size = | k-spot = K-105 | hill size = HS 117 | hill record = 120.5 m (395 ft)
{{flagicon|NOR}} [[Jan Christian Bjørn]]
(21 March 2009) | championships = | olympics = | world championships = }} '''Kløvsteinbakken''' is a [[ski jumping]] large hill in [[Meldal]], [[Norway]]. ==History== It was built in 1946-1947 and owned by Meldal IL, Orklahopp. First official competition was held on 7 February 1948. It hosted one [[Fédération Internationale de Ski|FIS]] [[Ski jumping World Cup]] event in 1988. [[Jan Christian Bjørn]] holds the hill record. ==World Cup== ===Men=== {| cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" border="1" style="background:#f7f8ff; font-size:90%; border:gray solid 1px; border-collapse:collapse;" |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" !width="90"| Date !width="69"| Size !width="200"| Winner !width="200"| Second !width="200"| Third |- | 18 Mar 1988 | align=center|K-105 | {{flagicon|NOR}} [[Erik Johnsen]] | {{flagicon|AUT}} [[Oliver Strohmaier]] | {{flagicon|CZE}} [[Jiří Malec]] |} {{coord|63.0433|N|9.6855|E|source:wikidata|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Klovsteinbakken}} [[Category:Ski jumping venues in Norway]] [[Category:Sport in Norway]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1948]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox venue | name = Long Island Arena | nickname = | image = | fullname = | former_names = | location = [[Commack, New York]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = 1956–1959 | opened = 1959 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = 1996 | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = [[Ice]] | scoreboard = | estimated_cost = | suites = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 4,000 ([[Ice hockey]])
6,500 ([[Basketball]]){{cite book |last=Hassan |first=John |title=The 1998 ESPN Information Please Sports Almanac |year=1997 |publisher=Hyperion Press |location=New York |isbn=0-7868-8296-4 |page=552}} | record_attendance = | dimensions = | tenants = {{infobox stadium/tenantlist | tenant_clubs = [[Long Island Ducks (ice hockey)|Long Island Ducks]] ([[Eastern Hockey League|EHL]])
[[New York Tapers]] ([[American Basketball League (1961–1963)|ABL]])
[[New York Nets]] ([[American Basketball Association|ABA]])
[[Long Island Cougars]] ([[North American Hockey League (1973–77)|NAHL]])
[[Long Island Ducks (basketball)|Long Island Ducks]] ([[Eastern Basketball Association|EBA]]) | tenant_years = 1959–1973
1962
1968–1969
1973–1975
1977–1978 }} }} '''Long Island Arena''' (also commonly known as the '''Commack Arena''') was a 4,000-seat [[indoor arena]] in [[Commack, New York]] from 1959 until 1996. The [[Long Island Ducks (ice hockey)|Long Island Ducks]] of the [[Eastern Hockey League]], a popular team in the small community, called the Arena home from 1959 until the league folded in 1973, one year after the [[New York Islanders]] came into existence.{{cite news |last=Teaford |first=Elliott |title=Mighty Ducks '93-94: Premiere Season |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=October 3, 1993 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1993-10-03/news/ss-42595_1_long-island-ducks |accessdate=2009-09-06}}{{cite journal |last=Levin |first=Dan |date=March 31, 1969 |title=If You Like Hockey, Basketball And Fierce Fighting Fans, Go Out To Commack, L.I. |journal=[[Sports Illustrated]] |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1082250/index.htm |accessdate=2009-09-06}} The [[Long Island Cougars]] (an affiliate of the [[World Hockey Association|WHA]]'s [[Chicago Cougars]]) also played at the Long Island Arena from 1973 through 1975.{{cite book |last=Gold |first=Eli |last2=Roberts |first2=M.B. |title=From Peanuts to the Pressbox |year=2009 |publisher=Thomas Nelson |location=Nashville |isbn=1-4016-0436-6 |page=67}} From 1968–1969, the Commack Arena briefly served as the home of the [[New York Nets]] of the [[American Basketball Association]]. Before the team's move to Long Island, the then-New Jersey Americans had scheduled a game against the [[Kentucky Colonels]] at the Commack Arena on March 23, 1968. The Americans and Colonels were tied in the standings, and a "play-in" game to determine who would qualify for the playoffs. The Americans were forced to move the game at the last minute because their normal home, the [[Teaneck Armory]], was booked with the circus. However, when the Colonels and Americans arrived at the arena, they found the court full of holes and laden with condensation from a Ducks hockey game the previous night. The court was also unstable. The Colonels refused to take the court under these conditions. The league ruled that the Americans had failed to provide acceptable facilities and forfeited the game to the Colonels, 2-0.{{cite news |title=American's Playoff Game in Commack Is Called Off |url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0D10FE3A5910738DDDAD0A94DB405B888AF1D3 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 24, 1968 |accessdate=2010-02-18}}{{cite news |title=Twenty-Five Years Later, Boe Makes Up for Mistake |last=Wojnarowski |first=Adrian |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/playoffs2003/story?id=1562700 |work=ESPN.com |date=June 3, 2003 |accessdate=2010-02-18}} The [[Long Island Ducks (basketball)|Long Island Ducks]] of the [[Eastern Basketball Association]] also spent one season playing at Long Island Arena during 1977–1978.{{cite news |title=Life Is Grim in the Boondocks of Basketball |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1978/02/01/archives/life-is-grim-in-the-boondocks-of-basketball-eyes-on-the-nba-life-is.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 1, 1978 |accessdate=2010-03-03}} Along with hockey and basketball, the Long Island Arena was used for ice skating, the circus, the Suffolk County Fair and concerts. [[Peter Frampton]] recorded part of his 8x platinum double album, ''[[Frampton Comes Alive]]'', at the arena. [[John F. Kennedy]] made a visit to the arena on November 6, 1960 while campaigning for the presidency.{{cite news |title=Kennedy to Attend a Rally in Suffolk |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 6, 1960 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1960/11/06/archives/kennedy-to-attend-a-rally-in-suffolk.html |accessdate=2009-09-06}} During the 1980s and 1990s, the Long Island Arena housed a large, indoor flea market until the facility closed on July 31, 1996.{{cite news |last=Hernandez |first=Carol |title=Vendors Say Goodbye to the Arena |newspaper=[[Newsday]] |location=Long Island |date=July 14, 1996}} A shopping center, consisting of [[Target Corporation|Target]], [[Hobby Lobby]], and a [[Whole Foods Market|Whole Foods]] supermarket scheduled to open in 2019,{{cite news|last=Parrish|first=Tory|title=Whole Foods moves forward with new LI locations|url=https://www.newsday.com/business/whole-foods-garden-city-1.17516330|accessdate=2018-05-19|work=[[Newsday]]|date=March 20, 2018|language=en}} among other stores and restaurants, now stands on the former site of the arena, which was located on the south side of [[New York State Route 454|Veterans Highway]] just west of the [[Sunken Meadow State Parkway]].{{cite web|title=Commack NY: Veterans Memorial Plaza - Retail Space - Kimco Realty|url=http://properties.kimcorealty.com/properties/0575|website=properties.kimcorealty.com|accessdate=2018-05-19}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120313231444/http://www.commackhistory.com/liarena_2.html Long Island Arena (Commack History)] {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[New York Nets]] | years = 1968 – 1969 | before = [[Teaneck Armory]] | after = [[Island Garden]] }} {{end}} {{New Jersey Nets}} {{NewYorksportsvenues}} {{coord|40|50|18|N|73|17|0|W|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:American Basketball Association venues]] [[Category:Basketball venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Defunct basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Defunct indoor arenas in New York (state)]] [[Category:Demolished music venues in the United States]] [[Category:Demolished sports venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Smithtown, New York]] [[Category:Sports venues in Long Island]] [[Category:Sports venues in Suffolk County, New York]] [[Category:Defunct sports venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Former music venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:1959 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1959]] [[Category:1996 disestablishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in New York (state)]]
